reviews.review: Amazing!. It is a small animal sanctuary only a short drive from Cusco. The work they do is amazing! All the animals are super cute and the guide is very informative of each animal and why they are there. The squirrel monkeys definitely stole my heart! ❤️ Worth the trip for sure!
Short but Worthwhile. The tour is cool and informative but they also do good work here. A lot of the animals were inured or abandoned so they are kept here.

Close up! amazing place. Small but very compact sanctuary is a rescue home for many animal spices. Apart of typical peruwian animals like alpacas, wikunias, CONDORS, you can see black bear cub, hairless dog, 2 pumas, felis (predator cat), and many many other. Animals are being rescued from smugglers or found close by their dead parents. They also have first in Peru condor breeding program which is really interesting taking under consideration that condors have one partner for whole their life. All breed condors are being relisted back to nature in Machu Pichcu area. unfortunately such a big cause is not donated by government so they accept all donations. All products from their shop are from alpacas which lives in sanctuary. Good lesson for whole family, great place to visit..
Highlight of our Trip. We enjoyed out time at the Sanctuary. The animals were well provided for and very approachable. Be sure to leave a donation or to buy something to keep them supported.

AMAZING - This is a must do when in Cusco.. This was so much fun. You can't get this close to some of these animals anywhere else. I know someone else reviewed this and thought it was a sham but these people really are helping the animals. Like Puma that were rescued from a Discotech and have been declawed. They couldn't survive in the wild. The people are doing good work. There's a tour agent on the Plaza de Armas that will sell you a ticket and ride. You can find them on the sanctuaries website.

Close up of Lamas and Alpaca. Small and Compact Animal Sanctuary where you get fence -close to Lamas and different coloured Alpacas. Get to see loom weaving by weavers and shop at the amazing store. Tourist prices but for those who have no time to shop for Alpaca buys...this place came in handy. Good Quality of Alpaca shawls and sweaters.

They really care about helping the animals here. We were on a Sacred Valley tour, saw the sign, and decided to stop. For a very reasonable entry fee, we got our out guided tour to see llamas, alpacas, condors, and various big cats (probably a few more I'm forgetting). You can tell the staff really cares about rescuing the animals.

worth a visit. We stopped here while on our way to Pisaq from Cusco. We were given a tour of the facility by one of the volunteers. Some sad stories of animal mistreatment. There was no admission fee - donation only at the end of the tour. There was also a gift shop but no one pressuring you to buy anything.

Very nice stop, and no too "zoo-ish". hit this on our way out of Cusco and on way into Sacred Valley. Worth the stop. Staff was knowledgeable and animals were well cared for. Entry is by voluntary donation.

DO NOT VISIT!!! horrible place for animals!. This place is a commercial enterprise pretending to be a "non profit sanctuary for animals" while using the poor animals simply to make money. The animals ARE NOT released to freedom, don't believe any of the stories they tell you. This is pure exploitation of the animals and poor treatment of these poor animals for commercial purposes alone. DO NOT SPEND YOUR TIME AND MONEY in this place. This place should be closed by the Peruvian government and the people who run it should be thrown in jail.

More interesting than the ruins. We hired a motorbike and stopped off on the way to Pisac. 10sol donation and you get a little gift. The girl giving us a tour spoke in both Spanish and English and gave us lots of information about all the animals. I admire the work they do here and the staff seemed caring and passionate (they're all volunteers). A wide variety of animals. Obviously it would be better if they were in the wild but unfortunately that's not possible with some of them. For example the pumas had had their claws removed for performing in a nightclub so they'd be unable to survive in the wild. The work they're doing to release condors is excellent considering they have no government support. I found this tour more interesting than any of the ruins I saw that day and the next.

Saw a Spectackle Bear. Visited on a tour of The Sacred Valley a charitable organisation which rehabilitates and cares for the indigenous wildlife of Peru including Spectacle Bears,Condors,Pumas ,Llamas all appearing content in their outdoor surrounding.There were Monkeys and Macaws in a glass fronted shelter.We were asked for a donation of 10 Soles each which we happily provided and were given a key ring in return.You did have to exit via a gift shop but there was no pressure to purchase any local products on offer.

Lovely, caring place for animals in need.. I visited the sanctuary during my travel to Peru in September 2016. I’m animal lover and an activist myself, so this visit was kind of a ‘must do’.They are doing a great job out there. The place itself is not big, but animals are kept in good conditions, are well fed and looked after. They are working on new enclosures too, for example: for the spectacled bear they look after. I had a feeling that people working there are really keen and caring. It was a great opportunity for me to see some of the Peruvian animals, I wouldn’t have seen otherwise. OK, I’d rather see them living free, but also rather see them living safe lives in the sanctuary, than in bad hands. All the animals in there are rescued. People who work there told me many of their stories, some really sad indeed. They have quite a lot of species living there: lamas, alpacas, vicunas, parrots, tortoises (which I saw eating their lunch :) ), Andean foxes (stunning), pumas (truly amazing). And even a funny looking Peruvian hairless dogs. The sanctuary’s work on re-introducing the condor population in Andes is fantastic. It takes a lot of effort to breed those magnificent birds, and they are doing this out there. Some of the birds I’ve seen will be released soon. Once you’re there, you’ll have an opportunity to see condors flying. The experience is just fantastic.I have booked my travel to the sanctuary via an agent, but left a donation too, as I’m not sure how much of my fee would actually go to the sanctuary. So, if you go there, please dig deep, as this is what keeps them going.

Deeply caring staff to rehabilitate creatures - a feel good experience!. This is a rehabilitation centre not a zoo where animals and birds are wonderfully cared for, rehabilitated as well as breeding for certain species. This is my 4th visit and every time I leave (giving a generous donation) I feel good and friends with me are also are deeply respectful of the work being done to 'undo' harm caused by people trying to traffic exotic animals. It is wonderful to see and experience beautiful creatures close up such as the Condor and learn so much from the well informed guides. Truly worth a visit !!

A worthwhile road-side attraction. Returning from a day of birding in the mountains above Cuzco, our guide asked if we wanted to see Condors. Of course! Then he told us about this place, and we were game to go. A member of the staff gave us a tour and explained the many animals they are caring for. In addition to walking among threatened condors (that are being bred in captivity for release into the wild), we saw vicuna, giant rabbits, tortoises, "domesticated" pumas (so doomed to living a life behind bars), Peruvian hairless dogs, and several species of parrots that had been injured or clipped and could not survive in the wild. The admission fee was only about $3.50 and worth every penny. After learning about the amazing conservation work the staff is doing, we made additional donations. We arrived just before closing time, so we could only gaze at the lovely gift shop and snack bar through the windows.

Great place to see conservation in action.... Great place to see conservation in action. Condors at close quarters indigenous dogs - friendly and very informative staff and relaxed atmosphere. I was not under pressure like other folks who were whizzed through on their bus tours of the sacred valley. Take the time to ask and speak to the people to understand the local issues. Good stuff.

Great morning out from Cusco. After being in Cusco for a few days we were looking for something a little different from museums and inca sites and we discovered this place.The sanctuary clearly does some good work and really glad we visited. Hope they manage to keep it up.

Non-profit, donations welcome, it's pretty awesome. I wasn't here for long. Met Albert, my tour guide, at the beginning of the sanctuary and I was surprised there was no entry fee. He showed me around and told me how all the animals came to be there and their plans for them. Beautiful llamas and alpacas and they even have a little bear cub running around like a puppy. Se llama Moses. The condor exhibit was pretty cool, too. There's about a half dozen and they sometimes fly from one end to the other. Impressive to witness. At the end, they ask for a donation. I gave 10 soles and received a free gift. I also spent a little in their gift shop, which also goes toward their cause.Enjoy!

Sincere people. The animals here have been rescued from animal traffickers. The people working here seem genuinely fond of the animals. Efforts are made to reintroduce the animals to the wild, though some, born and reared in captivity, will not be able to survive in the wild. There is also a handicraft centre where traditional weaving is done, and you can buy some of these products in their shop.

Worth the time to Visit. If you want to see llamas, pumas and condors up close, this is a worthwhile visit. The tour specialist at the sanctuary will make the condors fly while you are in the cage. Great photo opportunities with llamas too. Plan to spend about thirty minutes to one hour. The sanctuary is small, but worth the time to visit. Thumbs up!!!

Great fun. I read about this place on a google review about sights around Cusco, and that review mentioned something about a baby bear. And because I have been wanting to see a spectacled bear ever since hearing David Attenborough narrate a documentary on the cutest mother-cub story, I dragged my boyfriend here. We saw lots other than Moises the cute but kinda shy and mischievous bear. There was a broken-beaked toucan, lots of vicunas and llamas and alpacas, and the guides will tell you the differences between all of them. Vicunas are the most expensive ones. But security is pretty tight here so you wouldn't be able to shave or smuggle or kidnap anything from here. There's also a couple of big cats, and even a condor flight show. Lots of different types of monkeys and birds. Best part is that visitors help support an awesome cause. Take a bus here from Cusco and haggle the price down (most operators know this place by its name so it should be easy to find, and it's located right by the main road), it should cost a little less than going to Pisac.

Helping the animals. This place was a great surprise. They are in the business of looking after Andean animals that have been rescued from traffickers or poor conditions. The staff here clearly love the animals and do their very best to look after them. Yes, the animals are in enclosures but often they cannot be released (eye damage, claws removed by cruel owners etc). You will see Andean Condors swoop to collect their food, pat Alpacas and come close to wild Cats and bears. It's an easy way to see a stack of animals that you probably won't come across in the jungle. Plus, you are supporting one of the few NFP services that help some of these highly endangered species. The tour is technically free but you should give a sizable donation to support this worthy cause (we gave 100 Sols each).

Amazing place!. We stopped here on the way to Pisac from Cusco - what a brilliant place! The staff were very well informed and passionate. We saw pumas, baby armadillos, condors, wild cats, vicuñas and many more. We also got to hold the tortoises and stroke the alpacas and llamas. Try and leave a generous donation at the end as these alone are what is keeping the sanctuary running.

Go and support their efforts. Upclose and personal with many of the local wildlife that has been rescued and many who are awaiting to be released. Go and support them with donations (no charge to go in). The experience is amazing.

A great place doing important work. Visited the sanctuary as part of a Lares Valley trek. It was wonderful to see puma and condor, although sad that they needed to be at a sanctuary. The staff were wonderful and very knowledgeable. The animals are well cared for and happy. They were in the process of building a new enclosure for the speckled bear cub when I was there. Well worth a visit and support for their work.
not my thing. The animals looked sad. They were confined to what appeared to be somewhat small areas, especially the condors who are enormous and couldn't fly far.

A must see. What a treat to see the native animals of the region up close. The staff provided up close experiences with the animals as well as interesting information about each animal. The highlight was the flight of the condor right above our heads! The staff are caring. All that and you are making a donation to support the work there!

an animal recovery center is clearly needed. It was heart -warming to see the mission of this place -- to rescue seized and unwanted wild animals. The Andean condors and pumas were particularly compelling -- and their stories heart-rending. However, we were dismayed to see the baby spectacled bear in a tiny concrete enclosure where he was exhibiting neurotic behavior due to his cramped quarters -- he was frantically pacing back and forth ---and the same goes for another animal in a dark box in the middle of the sanctuary -- maybe a coatimundi? It was hard to see what it was. Overall we admired the work of this place but felt strongly that a few of the rescued animals needs were clearly not being met due to insufficiently sized and barren enclosures, and this greatly concerned us.

see the condor and other typical andean animals. this is a non profilt animal "hospital". They help wild animals being found hurted or in private and hostile environments. You learn a lot about them and see the condors fly landing just in front of your feet - no reason to be frightened ;-)
Very impressive work. This is a must stop for anyone concerned about the environment and animal protection. Great for all ages.

Neat sanctuary, wish the facility itself was better and better maintained. This is a neat "roadside" attraction with the ability to interact direct with rescued llama, alpaca and other animals. Amazing display with the condors in their enclosed area that you walk into. Conditions overall seem bad for the animals, especially for the monkeys. Restrooms exist but were nasty. They work solely on donations. It's a good stop to make if in the area.

Superb little place, they really care for the animals, and offer a great shuttle service. with the little resources they have, You can tell they are really rehabilitating them and trying their best to care for them, and the animals seemed happy and well taken care of. They offered a shuttle service to and from cusco and a guided tour for 20 soles which was amazing. the flight of the condors is something i'll never forget.they need all the help they can get so please visit and support them!

Superb sanctuary! Condors up close and personal! Fantastic way to see endangered local species !. We stopped at this sanctuary without expecting much and boy were we delightfully surprised. The English speaking staff are fantastic and explain about the rescues of these delightful birds and animals. There were amazing condors flying overhead and spreading their wings. Macaws that mated for life. Curious llamas always ready for a photo. Tiny monkeys, Andean mountain wildcats (leopards), vicuñas and guinea pigs. After seeing the great work being done here it was a pleasure to buy great gifts at the gift shop. Well worth a visit just outside of Cusco. It was a nominal donation for entrance. One of our favorite spots on the trip.
Fun half day!. The people at the sanctuary really care about the animals that they have rescued. We really enjoyed our time (and it was even raining when we went, so that says ALOT!).

Great place, fantastic people. The people working here are doing fantastic work. The Sanctuary is a non-profit working with injured, orphaned, and abandoned animals. The work they are doing to reestablish the Andean Condors is beyond words. We were lucky to be visiting when it was feeding time for the spectacled bear. He's adorable and a bit bashful, and certainly loves his fruit. The Andean mountain car was also a treat. They also had a selection of llamas, alpacas, vicunas, huge bunnies, macaws, toucan, and pumas! At the end of the tour, we also were treated to an explanation of the natural dyes used in the wool. It is well worth the trip to see the animals, and support this great cause.

a very important side trip. it was very funny for the amount and variety of local animals to be seen, it was a big surprise that we find this enroute to pisac and we just stopped for 30 miunutes, it was a delight to feed the alpacas and see the women make their stuff...

Loved it. We had a great visit. We loved seeing the animals! We spent about an hour here. It is a great experience learning about the local animals and seeing them very up-close. We loved touching many of the animals.

it was an interesting visit. thanks to ttc we could visit this absolutely charming place were you see local animals and also you get a glimpse of the techniques for creating colorful garments the inca way made from local materials as vicuna and alkpaca wool and tinted with organic colors from roots, herbs, earth and so on....very instructive and educational to understand the locals.

Please visit, they are doing good work here. We loved stopping here on our day exploring around to the Pisac area. This sanctuary is a family run private organization and are dedicated to rescuing and looking after animals which have suffered mistreatment of any kind. We would recommend a stop to visit and to leave a donation so that they can continue their awesome work. If you have children, this would especially be a great little detour while exploring around the area.
Nice museum for explainations of the Lama & Alpaka's. The museum is worth a 1/2 hr visit - then you can see some of the animals ( in roundup).It ends in their store,
Great break with the kids. This is a great stop with kids. Stretch your legs, pet some llamas and learn something about the different wool

great work. the sanctuary whist small do an amazing job saving, rehabilitating and releasing animals. the condor breeding program is an amazing initiative to boost their populations in the wild. the english speaking guide was great, very informative with a noticeable love of the animals..

Repopulating the Condor. This was a stop that we made on the extended Sacred Valley tour with Action Peru Treks. We were buzzed by the Condors as they left their enclosure and flew down to their meal on the ground near us. We also saw Pumas, Llamas, Alpacas, Monkeys, Toucans and more.

Sacred Valley Tour day. This was a wonderfully unexpected stop on our tour of the Sacred Valley. We got to see Condors up close as well as Llamas, Alpacas, Pumas and others. We also got to see a woman working on a loom and were shown how the beautiful colors of Peru textiles are created!

Great stop for animal lovers!. This was a great stop and added nice variety to seeing Inca sites all day. We hired a taxi to drive us up to this sanctuary (about a 1/2 hour from Cusco), wait for us, then drop us at Sacsayhuaman. It was a wonderful morning. The guide at the sanctuary was great and spoke English. We loved seeing the bear, llama, vicunas, alpacas, wild cat, puma, exotic birds, snakes, and of course condors. We spent about an hour there. Also, I'm not a shopper but I bought a beautiful scarf from their shop and wish I had bought more for family and friends. The quality and value seemed better than anything else I encountered the rest of the trip.

Worthwhile Afternoon Excursion. Ccochahuasi Animal Sanctuary is about 30 minutes outside of Cusco by private transfer - we opted to have the Sanctuary pick us up in the main square, and were efficiently transferred to and from the Sanctuary. A collection of animals including llamas, alpacas, vicunas, condors, small cats, spectacled bear, and birds are available for viewing. Individuals guides appear to be assigned to visitors as they arrive. The guided walk through the small sanctuary took about an hour, although they're quick to move you through the experience. A nice opportunity to learn about their rescue and breeding efforts in the local area - hopefully they will be able to expand their facility in the near future.

Best Stop of the Trip!. We were thrilled to get this experience. We booked our tour through Incas Chacana in the main plaza and were bussed up to the Animal Sanctuary. Our guide was incredible. He was so passionate about the animals and very clearly loved them and the work the Sanctuary does.We were able to have up-close encounters with llamas, an alapaca, turtles, a macaw, and a condor. We were able to learn about the process for alpaca shearing, fur dying and cleaning, and the process by which they make many of the textiles in Peru.

Awesome!!!. One of the coolest stood outside of Cusco. My wife and daughter loved it. First time I've seen a condor, let alone have it fly over my head. They have a speckled bear too. Well worth the stop.

opportunity to see the local wildlife and the caring people who look after them. This is a place worth seeing. Throughout the sacred valley there are animals walking wild, being herded or forced into posed photography. This Animal Sanctuary offers opportunities to see the major wildlife of this area in the care of people who are not after a quick buck. There is a store there in which one can buy woven goods at competitive prices and at the same time contribute to this wholesome work of animal rescue.

Highly recommend visiting!. This animal sanctuary is small but worth a visit. We saw all types of animals from the region, including Llamas, Alpacas, Vicuñas, Wild Turkeys, Parrots, Andean Condors, Monkeys, and many more. We were able to see the Andean Condors up close and fly above us. It was a real treat to see Vicuñas up close, too. They are not domestic like the Llamas, so they are only found in the wild.The animal sanctuary provided a tour guide that walked us through the animal sanctuary. There was no entrance fee but you are asked to give a donation of at least 10 soles. You're allowed to take a little souvenir for your donation. You don't need a lot of time here, but I highly recommend visiting!

Rare animals in captivity. This place is a good stop half way between cusco and pisac. with a small fee you get to see rare indigenous species that have been rescued and kept in captivity, some they set back free if its possible.. they have condors, pumas, a wild cat, macaws, vicunas, llamas, falcons, eagles monkeys and more that you get to see from up close! Worth the visit!
Visit to site. Nice visit... charming animals and families that care for them with a cute little craft area. Andean children running around

Great place to take the kids!. We live about 50 minutes from this place & always take our guests to see the animals. There are quides who are eager to show you around & even have a foto shoot w/the alpacas! You can even be in the "cage" with the condors and watch them soar to get their meat! Highly recommend this place!

Great Stop. We stopped here during a trip through the Sacred Valley and what a great stop. This is a small animal sanctuary for endangered Andean wildlife. They work on donations and volunteers and have done a very nice job with the facility. The staff is very friendly and happy to explain what they are trying to accomplish. Having only seen Andean Condors in photographs it was amazing to see them up close.

Great stop - the condors are amazing!. We weren't sure about this place before our visit but the privilege of seeing condors up close convinced us to give it a try. It was a quick but enjoyable stop and we bought some of our favorite souvenirs of the trip there. Recommended!

Disappointed. After all the positive reviews and photographs of this place, I was pretty excited to stop here. We, and the couple who came in after us, were forced to pay the 10 soles donation to enter, and did not receive the small gift other reviewers had gotten. We weren't given an opportunity to feed or touch the llamas and alpacas, as other reviewers talked about. We were given brief 1 sentence explanations, and were rushed to the next animal, and then practically shoved out the door. I'm going to guess they were about to close when we got there, and if they had said something, we would have come back the following day to get the true experience, instead of this mess we got, making us believe they were more interested in taking our money over anything else. What a huge disappointment.

Six Feet From a Condor!. On the Cusco - Pisac road. Magnificent condors, that will fly over your head, and perch almost within touching distance. Breathtaking.Plus the other wonderful animals mentioned. i think these people do a great job here, and deserve your visit. Plus make sure to pop to Awana Kancha just up the road, to feed llamas, alpacas, vicunas.

You get to pet the animals. Non profit org. Its a shelter for animals. They save animals. Its a great small zoo that shows off an small array of animals. Theres even a vultures that you can seriously get close too. The trainers let you in the cage and the vultures are trained to fly around. I love it. They have a lot of alpacas and lambs too. And parrots that say ola! No entrance fee but you are asked nicely to give a donation. Please don't be stingy its for a good purpose. Btw, they have free guides that tour you around the mini open air facility. I loved it!And if you havent seen perus' dog, its there. 3 hairless dogs abound. Funny looking dogs.

Amazing! Recommend to everyone! . This sanctuary is an amazing, family run, not for profit sanctuary that rescues wildlife of all kinds from poachers and traffickers. I visited for 2 hours today and wish I could have spent more time! The staff are well informed and happy to give insight into the animals backgrounds and future. We were fortunate enough to encounter puma, Vacuna, condor, wild cat, monkeys, Falcons, parrots, macaws and a baby bear! All which had been rescued from poachers or traffickers and taken to the sanctuary to improve their health etc before they will be released in the future. It was fantastic to see these animals up close and know that they are there for a positive and temporary purpose. I am so surprised this sanctuary is not more widely known or advertised, I would recommend absolutely everyone who visits Cusco to check it out!

Fantastic opportunity to see local wildlife. The Ccochahausi Animal Sanctuary is a scenic 30-minute drive outside of Cusco that happens to take you past the Saqsaywaman ruins and several vistas of the city. The sanctuary itself has a wonderful collection of animals that it took in after they were rescued by local police from abusive owners and illegal exotic pet smuggling rings, such as pumas, macaws and monkeys. They also rehabilitate other animals with the hope of eventually releasing them. At the time of our visit, they had a couple falcons.
Good short stop in the sacred valley. Interesting animals. The opportunity to be up close to the animals is excellent. The condors were very cool - bigger than expected.

Worth supporting. Stopped here briefly on the way to Machu Picchu. I was impressed by the enthusiasm of the volunteers and the passion of the owners at this small sanctuary. A positive impression to counter the thousands of chicken factory farms that Peru has.
we loved the animals. my wife liked a lot the technique used for their colourful dresses / attire...i loved the way the animals are kept in good condition.

Must See when traveling to Cusco from Sacred Valley. Our taxi driver asked if we wanted to visit an animal sanctuary to see condors. We said Yes, not knowing what to expect. We were amazed and impressed with this free (donations only) visit to a well kept, preserved animal sanctuary. The English speaking guide took lots of time to answer all our questions. The animals are 'rescued', many from domestic situations or illegal trafficking. Good for this sanctuary to provide natural habitats for them to rehab or live. We also loved the artisan textiles sold at their store, and found some beautiful pieces to take home.
Care of endangered species. This visit was unexpected and our driver included it on our trip to Pisac. Fascinating and a pleasure to see a bear, puma and condors in a caring environment.

Quick and fun. Fun stop between visiting Inca sites around Cusco. The sanctuary is small and houses llamas, alpacas, vicunas etc. that kids (and adults) can feed, pet etc. There are also animals rescued from trafficking or trade - rare wild cats, pumas, condors and more. The staff member who took us around shared each one's names and stories, making the experience very memorable.

ADMIRABLE. Our guide suggested that we stopped in the Sanctuary even though it wasn´t on the itinerary. I was so glad we accepted.They rescue animals from trafficking or hunting. They had monkeys, turtles, condor, alpacas, vicuñas, llamas and much moreIt is a great experience watching the rescued condor fly towards you!!!I strongly recommend this placeTips help the mission
Quick Tour. This animal sanctuary is awesome. It is small but has a variety of native animals of Peru, Condors, Lamas, Alpaca, Monkey, Bear. The staff were very friendly and welcoming.

Wonderful look at the less commercial side of cusco. This is not a zoo but more like a rescue for abandoned or illegally captured animals. Though it's very small, it's clear that the staff have a real love for what the do. There are many of their own pets there as well. There's a nice shop which is a bit expensive but everything is locally made and some profits go to the sanctuary. The little orange cat is insanely friendly. If you go to pet her you may end up holding her all day!

Very much worth a visit!!!. From the website for the sanctuary we were able to hire a driver for about $10 round trip each to take us from our hotel to the sanctuary. The animals were very well cared for and the grounds although small were very nice. The guide spoke English very well and gave us a history on all of the animals at the sanctuary. The condors were the best part as we got to go into the flight cage and observe them flying right over our heads!
Ccochahuasi Animal Sanctuary worth a visit. Ccochahuasi Animal Sanctuary is worth a visit! You will see CONDORS! Nice to see a place caring for abandoned and injured wildlife.

Small but worthwhile attraction on your way to Pisaq. Family owned animal sanctuary with a large variety of Peruvian fauna, including llamas, alpacas, vicuñas, Pumas, condors, monkeys and macaws. Leave a donation as it is a good cause

the inca trail was a courageous deed. we finished this hike as a family, we started united together and ended it united together also, there were some minute delays but our guide bruno knew how to deal with us, thanks again to qorianka tours for its help.

Sanctuary and Serenity. What a beautiful Place, it's not very large compared to Sanctuaries in the United States, but it was one of the cleanest and everyone I encountered was able to answer all my questions and genuinely seemed to care about the animals, and raising awareness for the Animals Continued Safety.
I left this tour with a huge respect for everyone involved.

Beautiful place with very interesting guided tour. Absolutely loved it here! Intimate place, yet with loads of animals, alot of which i have never seen before in real life. Our guide gave us a very detailled tour and explained everything in spanish (my gf had to translate the parts which i couldnt understand, it was funny :D ) then we saw the condors feed, which was scary and impressive. They explained to us were the animals were from, and the even had a small baby bear from the andes! Cute and sad, i hope that he recovers soon so he can be released:) they seem to care alot about the animals there, way better than any commercial zoo i have been to. If i had brought more money with me i would have bought some of their beautiful products to support them more. But i am definitely coming back:)

One Cusco's best attractions. This amazing place is free to the public, but you should definitely donate when you leave! It's a rather large enclosure where they keep all sorts of rescue animals (condors, llamas, vicuñas, dogs, mountain lions, turtles, parrots...) and you can go right up to most of them. The llamas will eat alfalfa right out of your hand, and the vicuñas might lick your hands. You can even go into the condor enclosure and see those beasts up close, I have to say they're absolutely terrifying. You can also see how they make alpaca textiles and use all natural dyes from plants. Their store has some of the best pure alpaca products in town (anything you buy on the Cusco street is guaranteed to be some fake-ish blend). I certainly recommend it, their products are legit, beautiful, and support a great cause.

Sad stories, happy ending. Condors flying over you, pumas, ocelot, vicunya and an peruvan hairless dog. Interesting. Tickets 10 soles a person ( ca 3,30 USD). When you buy something in the shop your (and your companies ticktes can reduce to zero). But the goods are extremely expensive. All natural wool/colors.What I consider ridiculous is that when you want to work here as volonteer you have to pay about 2500 USD for half a year. For animal lovers a must go (but the stories are sad). You can come ther out of Cuzco by ordinary bus (a few soles).

A great experience!. This was one of my favorite things on our trip to Peru. We saw many different animals and learned all about them. Its small, but very scenic and informative. Have your cameras ready to take pictures of their Condors flying. They get so close to you! Its amazing to see these wonderful animals up close. The condors were the highlight of the sanctuary. At the end, they ask for a 10 nuevo sole donation and give you a little pen for each donation.

Condors up close. I found this to be a very worthwhile stop on our Sacred Valley tour day, we got to see many Peruvian animals as well as get up close with a few condors, which by they way are some big birds. One of the best things about this place is their mission to educate the locals about some of the endangers animals in the area, but they are also hoping to be able to bread and release condors in the future to help increase the population.

A must do in Cusco. On top of all the Incan ruins this animal sanctuary is a must do in Cusco. It is small but a perfect opportunity to get up close to animals as well as support the organisations rehabilitation and care for injured and trafficked animals.
great animal sanctuary. an excellent place to visit. this is apparently a non-profit zoo that cares for injured animals. off the beaten path, but worth a visit

Great experience to be so close of Condors! . It was really nice to see those animals (puma, condor, llamas, araras). I do not like to see animals locked but they say it is not a zoo. They take care of them untill they are good to go back to nature life. Aurelio was a good guide at the local!

Glad we stopped. It's good to know this place exists. For a very small entrance fee you can see some animals up close. The condors were magnificent even though they are not that pretty. Well worth the stop. They have a small gift shop. If you purchase an item part of the proceeds go for the care of the animals.

Perfect while you're acclimatising. A three trip which is great fun and easy on the lungs while your not accustomed to the altitude. Llamas, alpacas, condors, Pumas, wildcats and vicuña small very cute etc. but the tour was made by the excellent tour guide Jimmy. You can see how much the guides love all of the animals, a very intimate and friendly attraction.

Very privledged experience.. This sanctuary was not a stop that was listed on our tour through Sacred Valley. It was an unexpected stop. So awesome! These guys operate as a non-profit pulling money in from small education outreach donations and local artisans providing weaving demonstrations and sharing cultural knowledge. First time I have ever pet a condor, llama, or alpaca in my life. They house a few of the animals sacred to Peruvian ancestral culture (Condor, Puma) as well as animals that have been an important part of Peruvian culture (Llama, hawks, wild cats, guinea pigs, etc). These animals earn their keep. The condor is something like 50 yrs old and has been putting on flight shows for the reserve for years now. What a privilege it was to stand next to and pet that Elder. A real treat seeing all of the animals, hanging out with them, and learning a bit more about them. Truly unique experience. Most folks who are not around wildlife or familiar with these animals should consider a visit. Nothing like seeing the animal peoples that inspired the Peruvian cultural monuments!

Great stop on the way to Pisaq!. This was probably my favorite place in Cusco after Macchu Picchu. Small animal sanctuary with many types of rescued Andean wildlife- some that you can pet! A real up close and personal encounter. The short tour is completely run by donation (suggest 10 soles) and is a wonderful little pit stop. Take the 30 minutes to check it out!

They love wildlife, like you love wildlife!. This is about animals, but I'll start with the people - the people who care for their wards.When I visit any animal sanctuary I expect the staff and volunteers to be animal overs but the flks I met here are truly "passionate" about the their work and the animals under their care. Our guide, Pedro, was both passionate and eager to share his wealth of knowledge about his charges.The sanctuary is part petting zoo ( where you can touch llamas, alpaca, and native deer while learn the difference between llama, alpaca and vicuna), part Felidae refuge (where you can view pumas and an Andean mountain cat. SPOILER ALERT: To my knowledge, no one who likes house cats can walk away without wanting to smuggle the mountain cat home in a suitcase.), and part aviary. In addition the sanctuary has monkeys and tortoises.Several species of birds can be view - some caged, some not. The Andean condors are not caged. Visitors can get within arms-length of these magnificent birds which weigh about 11 kilograms (25 pounds) and have a wingspan of 3 metres (10 feet)! Having one glide over you, inches from your head, is an experience you're not likely to forget!

Great little wildlife place!. My friend and I visited this wildlife sanctuary in August 2012. We really enjoyed seeing the native animals. We were able to go into the enclosure with the Andean condors and have them fly over us. It was incredible to feel the wind from their enormous wings. They are huge. I loved watching them hobble around on land too, they are not very graceful walking, too big. They do really great work here rescuing injured wildlife. Great place to visit and donate to.
Interesting place. If you have an extra hour and are around the area go to this place. The animals you will see here were rescued. You can be very close to the stately Condor

Amazing . Jimmy showed us around and it was fantastic. The people of this sanctuary are real heroes! Seeing an Andean condor up so close was a real memory for life. They have plenty of other animals too (including wild cats and pumas). Just wished I left a bigger voluntary contribution at the end of the tour (Ccochahuasi should set up a PayPal account for more voluntary contributions).GO!!! You won't regret it!!

Anima Rescue. This a good change in pace from Inca ruins. They have a great dedication to preserving wildlife and rescuing injured animals. There are llamas, alpacas, cats, pumas, turtles, condors, hairless dogs, parrots, and more. They also demonstrate natural dyes and weaving skills. A donation of 10S per person is requested in exchange for a small gift. Well worth the time! It takes about 20 minutes to do the tour.
An interesting side stop. The sanctuary does an admirable job of helping to rescue wild animals from abuse and injury. The operate on donations and I would recommend a visit as well as a donation.

Get Close to the Wildlife of Peru!. Really worth a stop! The guide will help you understand the rehabilitation, breeding and release goals of the sanctuary. Special treats were the condors, pumas, llamas and vicunas!
A good break on your road trip. It was a interesting stop. Nice to see they are helping the injured and endangered animals. There was no charge to enter. Nice friendly people.
Excellent!. Excellent views and animals of the andean life, i recomended the condor´s fly is very intense and beautiful

A Must-See for Animal Lovers. I included a trip to this animal sanctuary on my free-day while in Cusco. However, while touring the Sacred Valley with our private guide, she kindly agreed to take us there early since it was on the way to a town. I was ecstatic! At the entrance, we met with a sanctuary guide who was so helpful and informative. He took his time to show us each exhibit and interact with some of the friendlier animals, like the alpaca and deer. We even got to go into the condor habitat and see one of them fly. Their wingspans are huge! It was sad to hear about the abusive histories of some of the animals, but I was glad to see they're in a safer place. I read some reviews of people complaining of the habitats animals are in, but the staff are doing what they can with the limited resources they have. This is not America and we need to be mindful and sensitive of that. They are doing what they can and I applaud them for that.At the end of our tour, my husband and I gladly gave a donation.

Day Trip to The Animal Sancutary. Yes I was grumpy and running low on sleep, but we took the bus form the Cuzco square and it took 2 hours to get to the park because we had a quickie drive through tour of everything in Cuzco. Same on the way back. We only were given about 30 minutes at the sanctuary and at times I was doubting how much of a sanctuary I was at. They make the condors fly over you, it is cool... but I have a feeling the condors don't appreciate being chased and forced to fly.Hindsight I would have skipped it, not sure why it has such a high rating on Trip Advisor.

Have low expectations. So I just went today with my wife, after reading a ton of reviews this was a must. After finally figuring out through their website that is improperly listed here (google it) you can buy your ticket and get transport to their location for S/ 30. Great deal right? Well everything went smooth till 15 people got into a van made for 9 tops. We got to the sanctuary, it did have good parts like close contact with local animals. However you are rushed through with a guide there is no taking your time at the exhibits. The animals are in very cramped quartets, especially the fox who was essentially in 4' x4' cage. There reintroduction plans for young animals is sad. They have a 6 month old condor that has no space to fly more then three flaps. The young puma who they plan or releasing has little to know real world experience as it lives in a cage with its mother and two adults.  At the end of the day I know they mean well and I did donate knowing that they are doing good things for animals in need. They truly need help from a zoologist or two which is why I would still say go do they can make improvements.Lastly the way home. What a mess. We were dropped off at the blanco Jesus. The driver said ten minutes. Before we knew it everyone was out of the van and on a tour bus. After a minute a person other than the driver came over and informed us to head into the bus. 40 minutes later we finally made it back to Cusco. This is my experience I hope yours is better.

Interesting.. We got to see a Condor, which was magnificent! Wingspan of about 18 feet and they had then flying, then standing beside us. Great idea to help the animals but not too much else to see. It was on the tour but could have missed it.

So amazing to see a condor close up. We were so fortunate to make the trip to this valuable sanctuary. Volunteer guide Aurelio was so passionate about the work they do here in saving such beautiful animals. The Macaws were gorgeous, as w ere the llamas. Having the Majestic condors flying so close to us and having photos with them was a fantastic experience.

A Highlight of our Trip!. We visited Ccochahausi and it was such a wonderful experience! They are doing so much amazing work with these endangered and once abused animals. The sanctuary is large, clean, and the enclosures are well designed. It was about a 30min drive from Cusco. A van picks you up from Cusco and the transportation is included in your ticket. The ticket is 30 soles or about $10. An hour guided tour and education about each of the animals is also included with your ticket. They are doing great work through conservation and education for Condors, Vicunas, large cats and many other species. Our guide was so great, spoke English, full of information, and answered all of our questions. I highly recommend spending some time here! They are non profit and privately funded so if you do go, please donate what you can to help save these amazing animals :)

The condors are worth the trip. I had no idea that condors were so HUGE and so ugly!? The sanctuary is small and reasonably well kept. The animals in this sanctuary are well cared for and interesting.

Getting Bigger. One of the nice things about living in the Cusco region is that I have the opportunity to visit places like the Cochahuasi Animal Sanctuary on a fairly regular basis and have had the pleasure to see it growing. When I first visited over 3 years ago they had, among other things, 3 condors, 3 pumas, and 2 vicunas. Now they have 7 condors with one mated pair, 4 Pumas (the new one is the offspring of two of the existing) and about 6 vicunas. They have also added many parrots and some monkeys to the animals that they are now caring for and while it is sad that this is something that is actually needed, it is good to see that they receive enough support to continue to grow and take in animals that are injured or miss-treated.

Fantastic experience with condors!. A very pleasant surprise during our stay in Cusco! After finding this sanctuary on tripadvisor, we got a taxi which took about 40 minutes to get there and absolutely loved it! The staff are doing excellent work at this sanctuary and they had fantastic and interesting animals to see and interact with. You can feed the llamas, step inside the condor enclosure and watch them take flight over your head! At the end of the trip, the staff only ask for a donation and you receive a handmade gift after donating. A brilliant experience and friendly, welcoming staff who are doing a fantastic job with the animals.

For what it is, time well spent. It isn't a big sanctuary but has adorable animals, llamas, Vecuñas, alpacas (?), birds, wild cats, pumas, condors and monkeys. A tour, including transportation from cusco, cost 30 soles pp. Our tour guide led us through the park, telling us about the animals and letting us touch most of them. Even the gigantic condors! Unfortunately the monkeys were in a glass cage but a worker let me in as it was my birthday and they were all over me, great experience. thanks for that!

More evidence of a culture that is as concerned about its ecological heritage, as it is of its cultural heritage.. Unassuming as you arrive, once you walk the grounds you will be hooked at the amazing things being done by this small volunteer organization that exists solely on the gratuities of travelers and visitors from the road. From the condors to the Pumas in residence, its a chance to see as well as experience first hand beautiful and majestic wildlife that graces Peru. Don't miss this stop if you get the chance to visit!

Small Animal Sanctuary, but big on photo opportunities!. Great to see Llama's, Alpaca, Condors all so well looked after. You learn some interesting facts about the animals, as well as standing near the Condor for a photo, this bird is huge! There is also a shop selling goods mainly made from baby Alpaca fur, which is softer than the adult version. It wasn't a cheap place to buy from, but genuine, which you are not always sure about when buying on the streets of Cusco. Lovely to see a traditionally dressed woman weaving, a great photo opportunity! These ladies have the patterns in their heads, which have been passed down the generations - no books or computers to check from. Great place to spend an hour or two.

An Accidental but well-worth-it stop!!!. Our guide knew of this place as we were headed back to Cusco after our Sacred Valley tour and offered to stop. It was a wonderful tour of a place that takes in all sorts of wounded or otherwise impaired birds and animals from Peru - Pumas, Condors, Vicunas, Llamas, Alpacas, Monkeys, wild Peruvian Cats. It costs nothing, although they ask for a donation, which one has no trouble making after the very personable tours given by one of the caretakers,

condors puma and llama guinea pigs up close. with all the attention to inca ruins it wa sanice detour to see these wild life up close ,the keepers also coaxed the condors to fly for us so we got a real close visual on their wing span also saw lady weaving and using various colors to make an intricate design.

Misadvertising at its worst. We were very excited to go to the animal sanctuary - to see Andean condors and other indigenous species up close. We went to the main square in Cuzco to their office to sign up for an excursion and were told it would be a half hour drive out, one hour with the animals, and a half hour back. Fine. But that's not how it worked out. It took 70 minutes to get out there, not because it was a far distance, but because it was a "tourist" route with a drive through the squares of Cuzco, and a stop at one of the ruins to take pictures. Really?!? We were confused. When we arrived at the sanctuary, we were rushed through in 27 minutes. Yes, we did spend some quality although very brief time with the condors, but everything else was a "run through". And the guide didn't mention the hairless dogs that were there (which we were told elsewhere were bred in Peru because of the fleas). Nor were we told of other cages which held species of monkey indigenous to Peru, many more birds, and who knows what else. Frustrating! There was also a gift shop which sold items made from alpaca hair - fine, beautiful, colorful, well-made items whose sale was intended to raise further money for the sanctuary. However, there was little time for us to purchase anything. Thankfully I was made aware of this by fellow tourists and was prepared mentally beforehand to know exactly what I was looking for. The bus driver very rudely ordered us back on the bus. Vamoose, vamoose! And now began the ride back with yet another lengthy stop at another ruin for pictures, time which would have been better spent at the animal sanctuary. Now we were doubly and triply frustrated. Thankfully, we were not the only ones. And thankfully, one of our assorted group spoke fluent Spanish. He expressed his frustration, politely, to a tour guide on the bus but was brushed off. Four of us decided we needed to go to the main office back in Cuzco and speak out rather than let other people be railroaded through such a disappointing experience. There we were told that we hadn't read the information correctly on the website, or that the person who signed us up and took our money hadn't explained things correctly. When we went to the website and pointed out the specifics, he refused to listen. We don't speak Spanish, and he refused to acknowledge us until....I looked him straight in the eye and said that I would go on TripAdvisor, express our disappointment and discourage others from going. Immediately he understood me and offered a full refund. Did we take it! Yes, because they were in the wrong.If you go on this excursion, make sure you have all details in place. You can even refer to this review. This could be a very wonderful experience if you get what is advertised on the website. The rating we give refers to our total experience, not to the sanctuary itself.

Highlight of Cusco, great to get up close with the animals of Peru!! Puma's - wow!!!. This was a highlight for us seeing the animals, it still bothers me they are in captivity but at least they have been saved from traffickers etc. They are well looked after and some will be released back into the wild. If takes about an hour from downtown Cusco. A guide will show you around and you can get up close with many of the animals, Lama's, birds, Peruvian Dog and Concords. Our guide was very informative, we learn't about their habitat and how the environment has changed for many of them. At the end of the tour there is an option to buy local products to help support their sanctuary. It was all very educational and well run, highly recommend it. Beautiful animals!!!

A well-maintained sanctuary for Peru's animals. We visited the Ccochahuasi Animal Sanctuary to see some of Peru's most beautiful animals, and we were so happy we did! The volunteer staff was knowledgeable about animals, and they answered any questions we had. The condors and alpacas were our favorites! Make time to visit the gift store; the money goes toward maintaining the sanctuary.
Condor Experience amazing!. Fabulous wildlife sanctuary. The staff are doing an amazing Jobe protecting these beautiful creatures.
Amazing animal sanctuary. The condor was awesome! The animals there are amazing! Great tour guide and an awesome gift shop. Loved it all.

Watch birds and animals up close. We stopped at the animal sanctuary on our way to Ollantaytambo. There are various that are under care here. We saw llamas, alpacas, vicunas, pumas (but they didn't come close to us). We also saw different types of macaws and saw 2 big condors fly over our heads.They had a lady weaving wool of the baby alpacas and had a Peruvian 'hot' dog roaming freely.Well worth a 30 minute stop.
El Condor. Seeing the condor up and personal was pretty amazing especially watching the older one lord it over the younger male. i never realised they were able to live to over 60 years
Flight of the Condor. Loved this!!! It was definitely a highlight of our visit to Peru. We loved the sanctuary, the stories, and the Flight of the Condor. Highly recommend don't miss this!

Any animal lover must stop there. We asked our guide to see the special Peruvian dog, therefore, he changed our tour to see something out of the schedule (one of the benefit of private guided tour).We arrived to this animal sanctuary and met Lino Chaves Gonzales, who explained us the different animal in the sanctuary, with also demonstration of the condors (in one word WOW). Any animal lover near Cusco must demand to go to this Animal Sanctuary and to pay some money as a donation. It took us less than 30 minutes to see those poor animals and also the Peruvian dogs (a very special kind of dog), but we left there with a lot of satisfaction .

Enjoyable side trip. We had a lovely few hours here. You can get up-close and personal with animals you wouldn't otherwise have an opportunity to encounter. Bring your camera and your courage! As a knitter, my one sadness was that despite their impressive display of naturally dyed yarns, they weren't actually selling any of them.

Close Encounters of the Bird Kind. We had a great time at the animal sanctuary. Considering they arrange transportation to and from Cusco for you for only S/.30 each, it's a very good deal. You can get up close to a lot of beautiful Andean fauna: vicunas, llamas, alpacas, hairless dogs, rabbits. They have several macaws that you can hold, and they have a few aviaries with various birds of prey that were impressive. There is an enclosure where they keep the famous Andean Condors, and they have trained them to fly over your heads - very exhilarating, and it makes for great pictures.The best part is that all of the resident animals were rescued - either they were injured or orphaned. Those who can be are released once they are rehabilitated, and those who can not are kept safe at the sanctuary. This is a great cause which we were happy to support.The only complaint that we had is that it felt a little bit rushed, as they had to get the bus back to Cusco in time for the next group.We also used this as transportation to Pisac from Cusco - you can catch the bus across the road from the sanctuary for only S/.2.
Excellent. This is an amazing non profit sanctuary that helps rehabilitate injured and animals in need of help. Once they have recuperated they are released back to the wild.

a quick stop but definitely worth it. This is not a big fancy place but it's worth it to see the condors fly right by you and get some great pictures with them and other animals. There is also a chance to purchase some handmade alpaca goods (and other things), they seemed to be better quality for the prices compared to other places.

Worth a stop!. My taxi stopped here on the way to Pisac. I went on a quick tour (10-15 minutes), which included an explanation of the different camelids (llama, alpaca, vicuña), and viewing of other local animals like pumas and condors. The guide took my picture with an alpaca and a condor. There is no entry fee but there is a donation box. As this organization's aim is to promote animal well being and protect endangered species, I encourage donations! I highly recommend heading here to familiarize yourself with the animals of the area.

Wonderful sanctuary!. We stopped here on the way to the Sacred Valley. We got to see native species up close including the Andean Condor (who seemed fascinated with the contents of my purse); the Vicuna; the pumas; wild cats (they are both beautiful and crazy); the Peruvian hairless dog; different species of birds; llamas; and alpacas. The people who run this sanctuary are kind and committed to saving these animals. Definitely a worthy cause and a great place to stop to appreciate species which are endangered but will hopefully be saved with the efforts of people like those who run this facility.
Interesting animal sanctuary. Awesome tour ! There's nothing like hugging a llama and having a condor fly right toward you! A great place with an admirable mission.

Animal Encounters and Education. Where else can you have such good face-to-face encounters with Peruvian animal life, especially wild species? And the sanctuary does important educational and conservation work.

A Nice Animal Charity and Visit. This a non-governmental charity that takes care of injured animals. It is about 20 minutes from Pisac. We were given a tour by the staff and saw alpacas, llamas, vicunas, parrots, pumas, eagles, even condors -- my son was able to feed a couple of them. We even got into an enclosure w/ the condors and saw them fly. There is no admission fee but donations are welcome. The charity also runs a store where you can get alpaca and other goods, which supports its mission. A very refreshing visit after climbing the Pisaq Ruins!!

Outstanding!. This was an unexpected stop, and ended up being one of our favorite parts of our trip. Great people doing great work. The animals are so cool!!!! The flight of the condor was spectacular. I can't say enough good things.

Met cousins of the Camel. On the way to PISAC stopped to see this animal sanctuary where I got to see for the first time one ALPACA and the other cousins of the CAMEL. This is a must to get to know the Peruvian pack horse.

Condors and pumas. Awesome value ,although it takes 3/4hour from Cuzco to get there, and the same back but its a great option and you are supporting a brilliant conservation cause... and they really really need the money , and it shows. So buy something from the shop or give a donation.

You should always visit an animal rescue centre. Great to see condors fly. They do what they can with very limited funds and they need more visitors. They run a bus from the centre of Cusco which is included in the fee.

They Do Great Work Here. Our tour group stopped here and we took a informative tour. The guide introduced us to many of the local wildlife which they rescued. This is a not for profit sanctuary that is mostly supported from the tours and sales in the shop that they operate. They take in distressed wildlife - nurse them back to heath and then. if possible, release them back into the wild. I urge all to stop by, take the interesting tour and support this worthy cause.
Fascinating. It was amazing to see the animals that were rescued. we saw Condors, Turtles, Pumas, and pure bred Lamas with blue eyes.

Don't Miss This Stop on the Road from Cuzco to Pisac. Wonderful educational tour of this wildlife rehabilitation shelter, where you can see up close the Andean Condor, Pumas, bobcat, llama, alpaca, vicuna, etc. Staffed by a bioethicist and wildlife biologists with whom you can talk about issues in the care of these animals. No fee to enter, but please leave a donation to help support the work if you agree that it's important!
Chance to see a Condor. I liked that we were able to see animals up close, especially the condors. I also think have your video ready to catch the condor in flight.

Interesting visit. I went to their office and bought a ticket for the 130pm tour and I was the only one who went! I'm surprised they took just me. Anyway, the whole thing took about 2 hours. I was hoping to see more animals, but it was OK. The tour guide's English wasn't as good as my Spanish so we did most of the tour in Spanish. The tour guide told me at the beginning of the tour that I should tip him for his services (I hope this means they don't pay him anything and he's working for tips). A trip to the gift shop is probably in order, but too much pressure to buy something. I didn't feel rushed to see all the animals at all. Glad I went. I would recommend it if you have the time. Probably money better spent here than 25 soles just to walk into the church on the main square (in my humble opinion).
Worth it. The sanctuary is definitely worth the visit if you have time. Make sure to get your ticket from the right place though (see their website).

Wonderful work :). The group they took was not too big, so it didn't feel rushed or too touristy. Apparently there's only one agency that sells the tickets, which is across the road from Plaza de Armas.I loved the way they actually have a genuine interest in the animals they have. The guide we had was lovely and helpful and answered all of our questions. It's very easy to see all the rescues trust their caretakers and it was interesting to know more about them.Altogether it was a great experience, which I wold really recommend.

Great experience. This was my favourite excursion while sum Cusco. After seeing so many abandoned animals it was refreshing and heartwarming to see the dedication to animal protection. Very cool also to see Pumas, condors and monkeys. And I finally understood the distinction between llamas and alpacas!

great surprise. Our group stopped here and we were so surprised to be able to see all of the Peruvian animals up close....the puma and condors especially! The vicunyas were amazing too- they tried to jump through the fence and attack us- wild and untamed creatures! Beautiful birds, llamas peruvian hairless dogs, and alpacas. We loved the handicrafts here, and enjoyed the display of dyeing and weaving. Great sanctuary, with great care of injured animals. Well worth the stop!

An Absolute Must if you like Animals.. Ccochahuasi is a small animal sanctuary that does the very noble job of helping out animals that need help, animals that have suffered at the hands of humans, they get a second chance here. Here you can see llamas, alpacas and take pictures with them. You get to see several Peruvian hairless dogs, cuys, turtles, pumas, different andean felines, as well as condors. You can see them fly from one side to the other, it makes for an amazing experience. They charge 30 soles, pick u up from the Cusco Plaza de Armas, do the tour which takes roughly 45 minutes and then drive you back to Cusco, all for 30 soles (10 dollars). While you're there you can donate a little something, every cent helps. Give them a call and arrange for the pickup when you're in Cusco. You wont' regret it.

Surprise in the middle of nowhere. For a 10 sol donation, you get a personal tour and to see Peruvian animals up close. We enjoyed seeing and learning about the animals and the Sanctuary's rescue efforts. We also learned natural ways to dye the yarn and watched a young girl weave. Well worth the stop for a good cause.

Condors. This is worth a quick stop to see the work they are doing with the animals and also to see the amazing condors. This stop took half an hour at most. A guide will show you around and tell you about the animals and will get the condor to fly.

wonderful and unique experience. this was a wonderful opportunity to see indigenous peruvian animals that I would not otherwise have been able to see. It's really very inspiring, rather than sad. The sanctuary attempts to rehabilitate the animals and send them back into the wild if possible. If not, it provides a safe and comfortable environment for them while raising awareness. Definitely worth a visit!

Not enough time to look around!. We visited this sanctuary in March, but I was a little disappointed. We arrived and was assigned an English speaking guide who was very enthusiastic but seemed to rush us around very quickly. I thought that I would have enough time to take pictures afterwards but this was not the case. The Condors were very impressive but still caged non the less. They are also man handled to get them to fly over tourists heads! The whole trip took about an hour...(including the bus ride from Cusco)

Surprisingly great!. I wasn't enthusiastic about the idea of seeing caged condors but I was won over. It's so clear that the heart of this establishment is in the right place and it is heart breaking to realise so many of these animals have been rescued from far worse cages. It was incredible to see condors, lynxes, flimingos and more up close. I think they should build a small picnic area and maybe have a small cafe too. We would have stayed longer if there was anywhere to sit down. My kids would happily have stayed all day.
rescue zoo. I was so happy to see what this rescue zoo is doing for so many unfortunate animals. Very informative and such amazing animals and local crafts to see. A must!!

A good overview of peruvian wildlife. We really enjoyed our hour here. It came as a bit of a surprise but the location was great. We loved seeing the condors in flight even if they were not in the wild.

Great way to see some Andean wildlife. This was a really fun outing. You get info on llamas, alpacas and vicuñas, and later a pretty good explanation on traditional andean craftsmen turn the fur into fabric. And you can get up close to the llamas and alpacas (not viceñas - it seems they're nasty critters).And the highlight of course is the condors. You get to see them fly, see them up close.It's a great introduction to Andean wildlife, including the threats they're facing and the efforts being made to help repopulate them.A fun and educational couple of hoursSome logistics in terms of getting there from Cusco (because I found their website a bit confusing). There is a foreign exchange/tour place right on the Plaza de Armas called Inkas Chakana - it is NOT the place I found online called Chakana travel on Procuradores.The bus ticket/tour combo was great - we showed up shortly before 9 am, and were on the "bus" (in reality a minivan) about 15 minutes later. It's a very scenic drive, followed by which you get driven back to Plaza de Armas. A little over 2 hours in total. It's convenient and an easy way to get there and back.

Stood up by the driver. Had made arrangements for the 9am tour and made our payment online. Showed up to the meeting point 20 minutes early. When it was 10 minutes past the pick up time, I called and was told it would be another 15. An hour later, a guy shows up in an unmarked van and told me to come back for the later tour. Since we booked other afternoon tours, we just asked for our money back (to which he complied). Found the whole encounter disappointing and unprofessional.

Flying Condors!!. This place was recommended by our taxi driver. It is a sanctuary that rescues animals that are mistreated or abused and cannot return to the wild. Among the collection of many alpacas, llamas, pumas, tortoises, there are 3 massive condors. The cage is huge. Large enough to allow these majestic birds to spread their wings and fly. Absolutely breath taking. There is also a display of how the alpaca yarn/fleece is dyed using natural dyes, while a woman weaves some of the amazing tapestries. Unique, authentic treasures to purchase here as well.

Unexpected delight. Our guide for the day suggested a stop here and we were not disappointed. Seeing the rescued animals and hearing their stories was educational. Never guessed we would see condors. Shame on the humans who harmed the animals and kudos to those who operate the sanctuary. A treasure.

Awesome Peruvian jungle creatures who need support.. Great animal sanctuary. I saw the following animals (note this list is not exhaustive): - tortoises - alpacas - condors - falcons - pumas- monkeysIt's a family run organization and your visit helps. My heart was broken at the sight of one eyed falcons, pumas whose teeth and claws were removed for entertainment purposes, and Gonzalo the monkey, who was found crawling with parasites due to inadequate care. Not only did I get a sampling of native Peruvian fauna, I felt I was truly supporting an organization doing good work.

Another Trip Highlight. We stopped at the sanctuary on our way back from the market in Pisac. Our kids and I loved it. A staff member gave us a tour around the grounds and we were able to see many animals up close. We especially enjoyed seeing the condors! It is great to see somewhere so dedicated to helping these animals that need a home!

Condors--up close and personal!. Family-run, open-air animal sanctuary featuring llamas, alpacas, guanacos, macaws, bobcats, Peruvian hairless dogs, and condors. All animals have been rescued and are being rehabbed. The condors were amazing! You can walk right up to their perching spot and take a portrait with them. The caretakers can even encourage them to fly across the sanctuary so you can witness their magnificent wing span. This alone is worth the visit!! The sanctuary also runs a small weaving exhibit, which showcases how alpaca wool is transformed from fiber to colorful woven goods. Especially interesting is the simple exhibit displaying the natural origins of the most commonly used dyes for these woolen products. There is also a gift shop where I purchased a beautiful, reasonably priced sweater and clean washroom facilities on the premises.
Condor. Very interesting place. They are rescuing wildlife and trying to rehab for the wild. Wish there was not the need but we saw condors here.
Outstanding place to see Condors and other animals. Staff was friendly and helpful.. We got to see some interesting animals including Condors and Pumas.
Support!. Do not miss out on this!! Great opportunity to see exotic and local wildlife. Groups like these deserve our support and we can enjoy these wonderful experiences while we do that.
Must see. Really nice place near Cusco. A must see. Friendly staff and friendly animals.Take a taxi to get there kind of cheaper than the tour from Cusco.

Glad to support it.. As some have said before, there doesn't appear to be a great deal here, but what they have in the collection, and what they have achieved is terrific. Just to be able to sit close-up to a pair of Condors, on the ground and skimming overhead, was worth the trip alone, but then there are Llamas, Alpacas, various hawks, Peruvian dogs, various parrots, Coatis (?) and a little demonstration of Andean weaving. There is no pressure to buy or donate, though I am sure everybody does at least donate, as they appear to be doing great work for Andean wildlife.The site is on the road to Pisac, we went independently on a local bus and carried on to Pisac, I am sure operators in Cusco must offer this trip, and they do have their own bus service in and out of Cusco.

Quick drive, nice tour, good organization. We took an 11 am trip to the sanctuary. It was easy and safe to book in the office at plaza de Armas. We left on-time on a small bus (bigger than minibus), see official website. It was about 40 min drive. When we arrived we were split into two groups (Spanish and English speakers) and had our tours. The sanctuary is mostly for animals rescued from illegal smuggling operations. We learned about alpacas, llamas, and vicunas. We saw condors and saw them fly. We learned about natural colors used to dye the yarn (very interesting). We would recommend this trip to anybody who is interested to learn more about native and not so native animals and birds, and for those who may not have too much time. Oh, and your money supports animal protection efforts. Another thing, we felt safe during our trip to and from. Visit itself was about 1 h, but with transportation ~2.5 h.

Fun afternoon. Ccochahausi offers a shuttle bus that picks up in the Plaza de Armas every afternoon at 3:30pm. For S/25 they take you to the sanctuary and return you to the plaza…visiting the sanctuary is free, your visit is donation based. We had a wonderful tour and saw llamas, alpacas, rescued birds of all types, condors, rabbits, and more. The sanctuary gives you an opportunity to interact and see animals you normally wouldn't get the chance to. Many have been rescued from the black market and have injuries that make it so they could not survive in the wild. Overall I think Ccochhausi is doing a great job, especially considering they are a family-run project that runs soley on donations. Definitely recommend!

great job. on Dec 2, during our stay at cusco, we hired a taxi from inkatravels for the whole day and stopped at this sanctuary on our way to pisaqwe were the only visitors and were taken on a special guided tour of the facility and given explanations of the various animals housed there.saw the condor taking flight in the ground as we sat comfortably and watched... the eagle, macaw were great toohighlight was the cougar family esp the little cub... we put our hand thru the grill and petted it to heart's content while its mother rested nearby and dad paced a distance away...put 50 soles in their donation box and took a couple of souvenir pencils... nice experience for sure

A sanctuary for rescued animals. Loved it!!! Well kept/ We had a great guide that explained all about the animals they have there. They are rescued animals. Some from circus life, others injured, etc Very interesting. They also show you the process of dying their wool with the use of natural plants.Highly recommended.

Nice work. The sanctuary has a few interesting animals, including a tame llama you can pat. The real value is what they do. They rescue animals who've been abused, birds who've had their wings clipped and can't fly, condors, etc. it's clean and cool to see the condors fly, but there's not a whole lot to see. I liked the gift shop - nice quality and some proceeds go to the sanctuary.

Absolutely amazing animal and bird haven. Dedicated souls saving animals and birds from predators - Aka MAN - and giving them a sanctuary - sometimes for life - by providing for them in an amazing habitat. Condors, Pumas, Llamas, alpacas .... Please support this non-profit and the animals and birds will thank you.

Best Part of Peru. This was the best part of my trip to Peru; I enjoyed this visit more than I enjoyed Machu Picchu! The ride to the sanctuary is amazing in itself; you pass through the Sacsayhuamán ruins, a small town, and gorgeous views in general. On the way back our driver even stopped to let us take photographs of the scenery. Once you get to the sanctuary, it's a once in a lifetime experience. You are so close to all these animals who were treated terribly and are now being nursed back to health and given a chance to live and reproduce. Many of the animals you will see are also endangered. It doesn't cost anything to go (so they say but that wasn't my case) but they will follow you around the store and try to find a way to get money out of you; I donated 10 soles and was still haggled afterwards when they tried to get me to pay for a girl who rode up there in the same van even though she wasn't actually WITH me which pissed me off. You will find people trying to get money out of you everywhere you go in Peru though so I suppose that it's normal. All that being said, this is definitely a cause worth donating to. At the moment there is a two month old puma that you can play with so go go go!!!
family fun. kids and wife loved this place, and will long remember it. their exposure to animals was superb, they felt things were cared for well, and they talk about it still.
Nice stop along the way. Nice stop along the Sacred Valley, best part was seeing the Peruvian dogs that hang around. It's a good cause and could use some support if you have the time

Good way to help and learn. Birds and animals get food and protection at this sanctuary. The highlight comes with a demonstration of condors flying--one surprised me by zooming right over my head and giving me an intense sense of its size. We also got a kick out of a bunny that hopped through a fence and suddenly realized it was inside the puma cage. The rabbit gave a quick "uh oh" look and barely made it back out as the female got rose with great interest. The facility is small and simple; the animals seem well treated given their injuries or circumstances make it impossible for them to live in the wild. No fee, but every donation gets a warm gracias.

Worth the visit!. This was an unplanned stop for us but I am so happy we made it! This animal sanctuary helps injured, abandoned or endangered animals and allows you to get very close to many amazing species such as the Condor. The team here is doing a good job, there is no entrance fee, they only request a donation to keep the place running! The tour is about an hour and you can take some great photos!

Nice place to support local projects. We stopped here on our way into Cusco. There is no entry fee but on the way out they do suggest making a donation.
