They have someone show you around that explains the work they do and the different animals you are seeing. It maybe takes 15-20 minutes to see?? We did learn a lot and it gave us the opportunity to ask questions about the local animals. The place does great work rescuing animals from various unfortunate incidents. I have mixed opinions about the shop on the way out. It is set up so that local weavers can make money - and I'm in favor of that. They have some nice things (which are cheaper - but not as refined as what you will find in the Cusco boutique shops). I thought the lady working in there was way too pushy. I probably would have bought more if I felt comfortable browsing. But with her pushing things on me I just wanted to escape. So I grabbed a scarf, paid and left!

Up close with a Andean condor. It is a rescue sanctuary for animals. Definitely worth to visit. You will see the typical animals from this region being nursed back to health. To me what was truly amazing was the experience of being so close to the Andean condor. No where can you see them up close. Kudos to the team working in this sanctuary.
Great place to visit. Very good place to visit...very happy with the overall visit. Highly recommended.....Not sure what else to say regarding this location.

Nice place to help support the local animals.. We visited this very briefly on the tour of the Sacred Valley. We only spent a few minutes just to see the condors. Our tour guide was attacked by a new condor and was immediately put on "time-out" in a separate pen. After that they push the condors up to the top of the enclosure to get them to fly over your head. I felt a bit bad that they were herded like that for people's entertainment but this was a minor gripe. This location is supported by donations so please make sure to drop some money off.

Nice place to visit and support the refuge. We visited this as a stop on our Sacred Valley tour. We only spent a few minutes as the location is quite small but we were able to watch the condors in their habitat. One of them actually attacked our tour guide (the guide mentioned that the condor was a new addition and was still adapting). He was put on "time-out" in a separate enclosure. This place runs on donations so please make sure to drop off some money on the way out.

Great Stop on the Way to Pisac Market. Our private taxi driver suggested we stop here, and we are glad we did. We were able to see condors, pumas, alpaca, llamas, vicunas, parrots and other animals up close. The fact that they have rescued most of these is an added benefit. The cost, 10 soles per person, is minimal.

Close, personal, amazing animals. Went to this animal sanctuary today with 2 friends. We just walked to the main square in cusco and there was a man with a brochure asking people to visit. We had already looked it up on trip advisor and wanted to do it, so he rang his driver and within 5 minutes a big taxi was there to take us. 25soles each person. Taxi was clean and the driver spoke English. The sanctuary was brilliant!!! Puma, macaws, condors, eagles, lama, alpaca and more. Guide spoke English and told us about each individual animal. Where it was rescued from, why it was rescued, and if the animal was able to be re released. They rely on donations (as the actual tour is free, the 25soles is transport). Beautiful place and very nice people. Highly recommend visiting! 10/10

Great quick tour....make the trip!. Everyday at 330pm the Ccochahuasi bus picks people up from the Plaza in Cusco. For S/25 per person they will drive you out and back. Taxi is easy as well. There is no fee for the Sanctuary itself but donations are greatly appreciated. Overall this place is really nice and they're trying to do a good thing. Most of the animals are from the black market, others were found injured and they're trying to rehabilitate them. The tour is fairly quick but the staff are nice and quite knowledgeable. The Pumas are quite a site, especially the new born. About 3 weeks old as of this posting. There are also Condors, Andean Bobcats, Vicunas, Guanacos, Macaws etc..... Go take a look for yourself.....make a donation.....take some great pictures. Kid friendly for sure, but I am an adult and enjoyed it quite a bit.

A surprise to come across . On the way from sacred valley to cusco, we stopped here. It was a pleasure to tour the sanctuary. The grounds are not grand by any means, but we had an amazing guide take us around to share with us about each of the animals that are in rehabilitation here as well as the history of the animals in inca culture. There was also a display of traditional threads from the alpaca wool and how those are dyed. The gift shop has many beautiful items and proceeds go towards benefitting the sanctuary. Initially, we were unsure about stopping here, but we are glad we did. The condors are a special sight to see.

Free day? worth a look.. We asked our hotel in Cusco to book this. Within an hour the refuge bus picked us up. We were shown throughout the park with our own guide. This took about 1.5 hours. We were allowed to go up to most animal's and were even given a condor show. You can see they are doing the best the can with the little money they have. We also saw a puma cub. You won't regret going for the little amount it costs.
So much to see. I left she who rules to go see this as I was more interested in the other wild life in the area,but have to say her photographs seem to show I missed something special.

Wild animal rescue project. We stopped there on the way from Pisac. It's a wild animal rehabilitation project with few dedicated people working there. They run a small shop selling alpaca wool products to support the project. The prices are high but it all goes to the animal rescue. We bought a hand-made poncho. There's no entry fee but they ask either for a donation or a purchase. Please donate and support them

Saving wild animals. We stopped there on the way from Pisac. It's a wild animal rehabilitation project with few dedicated people working there. They run a small shop selling alpaca wool products to support the project. The prices are high but it all goes to the animal rescue. We bought a hand-made poncho. There's no entry fee but they ask either for a donation or a purchase. Please donate and support them

What a gem!. I am so thankful for people like those who work here, dedicating their lives to saving and caring for animals. We stopped here on suggestion from our hotel and I'm so happy we did. We got a great tour and got to go in with the Condors! We saw our first Inca Dog, three Condors (and got video of them flying) and Pumas! Very educational and they also have local artisan weavers and a beautiful gift shop on site. Donation only! Please be generous. Worth a visit for sure, one of our highlights!

Awesome!. This place takes care of animals that have been abused/neglected and/or cannot be re-released into the wild. They do great work here. Good place to go and get up close views of some rare animals and learn more about each species. Wonderful English speaking guide gave us a great tour! Thanks!

Glad we went. A bit small for the pumas and condors but they are rescued. Getting there: we showed up up the tourist info centre in the main square several doors down from Mushroom lounge & bar. They called the company for us, and within 5 mins our ride had come. 25 soles each for return trip & tour & we donated 10 soles at the place because we didn't want anything from the gift shop. You can pay by visa/maestro (& probably MasterCard) at the place. We understood the English tour even tough her English wasn't perfect.As for the animals - got to see vet cute llamas and alpacas (including teenage ones), went in the condor cage & saw them fly, 3 pumas up close, macaws, a fox, and some other peruvian animals and parrots. Also usual animals roaming free such as rabbits, ducks, guinea pigs and a beautiful stream in the middle. The animals seemed happy and well cared for, but needless to say pumas and condors need much larger cages than this family can provide.
Llama's to hug!. This was such a great place to visit, one of our highlights of the trip. Lots of animals to see and touch. Plus this supports a good cause!

Friendly Llamas. We stopped here at the sanctuary on our way to the Pisac market. It was an interesting place, with several animals, birds, reptiles, etc .The enclosures seemed to be adequate for the species they kept. It was good to see the giant condors had room to fly. The one thing that I didn't like, the Peruvian hairless dogs on the property looked like they were starving. The rest of the animals looked well cared for. They had a llama that was used for tourist photos, he was pretty cool. There is no fee for a visit, however a small donation is greatly appreciated.

A Great Cause. We weren't going to go here because of the rain that day but we decided to stop on our way to Pisaq. It was definitely worth it. The volunteers/workers there rescue animals from several places. The pumas, for instance, that were in the shelter were rescued from a show and because of the way they were treated in the show they will never be able to be released into the wild. The variety of animals there is also a unique experience and one can get a lot closer to them than in the wild. After you have seen all the animals they have a weaving display with a weaver in traditional dress. You don't have to pay anything but donations are encouraged and there is (quite pricey) gift shop available as well.

A bit of a tourist trap. I was really hoping to be able to write a better review for this place, but my experience just wasn't what I was hoping. My "guide" didn't speak much English at all, which I know I shouldn't expect, but the next tour group to go through had a guide that was fluent. Given they knew I was an English speaker, it would have been nice to get a guide that did as well. The animals are great and appear to be pretty well taken care of. At the end of the tour, I gave them my donation (while everyone stared at me to see how much I'd put it). They told me I had 15 more minutes before my driver would be back (I saw the driver off in the distance who was clearly ready). This 15 extra minutes is just a ploy to give you an escorted tour through their gift shop. After I was done, they asked me for $50sol for the visit. I told them I had already donated and they left me alone. Again, the animals were great and the drive to the location has some pretty amazing views, but the human interaction left something to be desired.

Excellent to see Condors up close. My husband was really disapointed when we only saw one condor in the Colca canyon however the trip to the sanctuary more than made up for it.It is great to be able to see the condors flying so close to you, they are quite majestic when they fly.Definitely recommend with children or on the way to Pisac.

Unique experience. The whole sanctuary is just lovely. Animals are happy and so friendly. The sanctuary made us feel that animals are treat with love and care. And they show by the way interact with us.
Do it for the animals. Worth a brief stop between Cusco and Pisac. Several different kinds of animals and very nice tour guide. Make sure to leave a donation as it's how they feed the animals.

The kids loved it. Our kids are loved it. Not up to the standards of US sanctuaries, but they do a good job with what they have. Our son wanted to see condors and this was a chance to do so and see them fly up close. The gift shop sells products to help support the sanctuary, they were a little pushy in the sales, but it was for a good cause. No entry fee, but they do ask for a donation.Worth stopping at.

Very Fun!. Our driver took us on a Sunday afternoon drive outside of Cusco on one of our "down" days. We stopped here and at Awana Kancha to see the llamas, vicuñas and other animals.At Ccochahuasi we were amazed at the various animals. It was a pleasant visit with an earnest and knowledgeable guide. And, where else will a condor swoop over your head?!

Excellent trip out from Cusco. We visited the sanctuary on a bus from the main square in Cusco. We had read about it and wanted to go, but just came across the bus by chance. We had a private tour, as we were the only English speakers on our bus. It was really interesting hearing how the animals had been rescued, and the work that is going on there. Also the dyeing and weaving is interesting too. I would definitely recommend it if you have a few hours and have seen enough Incan remains!

worth. This Sanctuary was really educational. They have animals who are quarantined and they also take care of exotic animals, that have been extracted from their natural habitats. Very interesting and worth cooperate with the cause.

Condors! Condors! Condors!. Our bus made a stop here on the fly. We quickly toured the grounds with high hopes of getting to see condors. Not only did we get to see them fly, we also got up close pictures with these fantastic creatures. We got there at feeding time which was hysterical because of the animated geese!The 'admission' is free, but after hearing how all the animals are saved from various horrors, we all donated generiously to help the sanctuary. Good for a quick stop over if you are traveling in the area.

Nice idea but sad. I visited the animal centre last week. It was a small operation fund purely by donations. There are a few animals that they rescue but cannot be released back to the wild. I think it is very nice of them to do this for the animals. However I cannot help to feel sad for the animals in captive although they are nicely care by the people in the centre, the cages are still very small for these animals. I saw 3 pumas there, one is a female puma they rescue from a night club, her crawls have been removed so she can never go back to the wild. I saw her in a very small area and just cannot help feeling sad for her. There are also 6 condors, they are huge birds, they also cannot be released to the wild so they are in a netted area. Tho its bigger then the puma cages but these birds are really big and have wings spread around 8 foot or maybe even bigger. Again the area where they were kept are not very high and not very big at least in my opinion is not big enough for these big birds. I understand that soneone has to start somewhere and at least these people have good hearts for the animals. We didn't bring a lot of money with us that day as we did not expect to stop by this centre. At the end we only donated 200 soles. So if you plan to go, please donate generously so hopefully in the near future they can expand their facilities so these poor animals will have a bigger and more proper home. After all it is a nice place to visit if you like animals.

A great place to Peruvian wildlife. I´m writing this review a couple of months later so apologies if the details aren´t spot on.We were having difficulty finding information on exactly when the bus left as one user had mentioned there was one around 3:00 every afternoon but that was it. We ended up asking in a tour shop near the square and the guy called the sanctuary for us who then picked us up 5-10 minutes later. I think it cost us 10 soles more because it was an unscheduled pickup but we didn´t mind as the money goes towards funding the sanctuary.The sanctuary itself was fantastic with more variety of animals than we expected. We were greeted at the gate by a young billingual guide who spoke excellent English and knew a lot about the animals. By luck we arrived a few minutes after a llama had given birth which was a fun surprise for the staff as well. There were macaws and other tropical birds and of course the amazing condors that swoop down over your head and are so big! Other higlights were the 3 pumas (two rescued from a discoteca in Lima), a cranky vicuña, 2 wild cats and a friendly deer.They didn´t push at all for donations but we were happy to give more at the end and then purchase some of the handmade products in the shop as it was probably the first place we were guaranteed to get the real baby alpaca wool products that all the market vendors claim to sell.Highly recommended!

Do not miss!. This place is incredible. We visited on a tour with our taxi driver on the way to pisac, it would be difficult to find alone! Our guide Maurice was very helpful and was able to tell us stories about each individual animal they had rescued and what exactly they are trying to do to either release them again or continue to care for them. No it's not the biggest place nor is it glamorous but they are trying there best with what little funds they have and it's very admirable. Don't understand other reviews complaining about size of cages or the fact that they are keeping them in captivity, they are trying to help, the pumas cannot be released right away as they were used as show animals in night clubs and they might not survive. If your unimpressed with the size of the space they have then donate more money and help these kind people out!

Trip to the Sacred Valley and Cusco. This is a very interesting stop on the way to the Sacred Valley. It was encouraging to see the native animals taken well of. A small donation ( maybe 10 sol) is greatly appreciated by the staff. We were given a condor topped pen,

Unique experience. a real hidden treasure, many locals didn't even know about it, I emailed them directly and they picked us up at the main plaza next day and took us to a very special sanctuary, it was not a zoo but a more unique place, we were able to be inside the condor cage and have a condor flying over our heads, what an experience. Their store is kind of expensive but we were into animals not shopping.

Better than a 3rd day in Cusco. Cool animals, you get right next to them. There were macaws just walking around everywhere, Condors that fly right next to you, and a puma in a cage. Very nice, like a petting zoo with better animals. They are still trying to get better organized, and they sell things like everywhere else, but still seems like they are trying to do good work.

Great animal sanctuary. This was a great place we stopped by based on TA reviews- it was such a fun experience! Beautiful animals and a great cause-I was swept up in the moment and bought a baby alpaca table runner for $300 and my tour guide laughed at me later, saying I had been swindled. I'll chalk it up to a donation to the sanctuary :)

Animals Up Close. The sanctuary does amazing work in bringing back to health wild animals and releasing them back, when possible, into the wild. There is no entrance fee, but the guide gave us such an impressive tour of the place that we really wanted to give a large donation. You can see condors flying, pumas and other creatures up close. The visit takes about an hour at most, so this can easily be combined with other trips in the Sacred Valley.

Awesome. Our tour guide brought us to this zoo on our way to the Sacred Valley. It was very cool to see all of the native animals up close. They even have a condor enclosure you can enter and see these birds fly. There is no entrance fee but expect to feel obligated to spend money in their store to help support them as they receive little funding. Definitely worth stopping at.

Help the animals!. During our visit to the Sacred Valley on June 21, our guide asked us if we would like to stop at this refuge, that we had not heard about. It is not a zoo but a care-center for animals that have been illegally captured (some for illegal trafficking) or injured. The staff are volunteers, some are students from the area who care about the animals. Any animal that can be is re-habilitated and released back into their environment but there are some animals that are outside of their territories (like the strange looking bird from Brazil) and have to remain as permanent ´guests´. The one-in-a-lifetime experience of being in a large enclosed area with the condors and then having them fly over your head is not to be missed. These condors are more beautiful than the young condors in Colca. On your way out, you will be asked to make a contribution to this refuge as there is no entrance fee charged. It is a very worthwhile stop-over and it is a pity that it is not promoted more; it only takes a brief stop!

You'll feel good having visited this refuge. I am not into zoos, and I don't like seeing animals in cages. However, each animal here has a much better home than where they came from. The guide will walk you through and tell you why they acquired each animal. For example, 2 pumas were rescued from a nightclub in Lima. Others were rescued from the black market. There are a few Peruvian hairless dogs that live there. These were neat to see and pet. The store benefits the refuge. They sell sweaters, stuffed llamas, t-shirts, hats, etc. You can tell the workers feel passionately about their work. It seems like they have done much good in the 6 years since they've been open.

One of my favorite things I've done in Peru. This animal sanctuary is a bit hard to get to but well worth it. We first went to see the ruins surrounding Cusco and hired a taxi from there (Qunqo). It is a 30 minute taxi ride. We paid 90 soles (about $27) round trip plus the driver waited one hour for us while we were at the sanctuary. When we walked in we saw several macaws and parrots out in the open and just feet from us. They had 5 giant condors, 3 pumas and several other exotic animals, all with their own story on how they were rescued and why they are there. All of the animals there are sick, injured, or were rescued from various tragic situations, all with the intention of being reintroduced to the wild when well again. You get to be up close and personal with each animal. The sanctuary is an amazing place with amazing people. We had the most wonderful experience there seeing these exotic animals up close, learning about different animal species, and even getting the opportunity to touch some of the animals. It is free to enter but donations are encouraged so be generous!

animal refuge. Good opportunity to observe wild animals at close. I could even touch a condor. It was a unique experience after seeing these huge birds in Colca valley in their original habitat. Please keep in mind that it is not a zoo but a rescue center for injured animals. The tour is free but they live on donations so please be generous with your contribution...

Condor Fly by. This rehabilitation facility for local animals. There are Llamas, Alpacas, Guanacos, puma, parrots and condors. We did not see the puma.The highlight is condors flying over your head. The condors walk up a hill and when the worker signals them they fly right over the heads of the visitors. There is also a weaving demonstration.One hour is plenty here.

Caring for the less fortunate animals. We toured the facility which rehabilitates injured or neglected animals. The area is set up to accommodate each type of animal including the mighty condor. A demonstration of weaving gives an appreciation for the work involved. The gift shop at the end of the tour helps to fund this worthy effort. This is a private facility not funded by the government.
An excellent place to visit. Excellent tour of the animal sanctuary! We especially liked seeing the Andean Condors in flight and the Pumas!

Only place to see a condor?. This is an actual condor rescue facility, and was told it's the only place to see one. We saw pumas (sacred to Peruvians), and they have llamas and vicuna too, although those last two are seen lots of places. Quick tour by a biologist includes having him call to the condors who will fly right at you and over your head (if you are quick enough, you get a great photo op). They exist on donations, and a tourist shop which has lovely things.
Must visit when in Cusco. One of the highlights of our Peru trips. Amazing place, great mission, wonderful people. Take a break from touristy Cusco and spend a couple of hours in a magical place.

Great mission!. We were really impressed with this place - great educational message, outstanding facilities for the wildlife and a nice selection of items to purchase to support their cause. We got most of our souvenirs here!

Loved this. If you love animals, this is for you. They have the cutest little collection of llamas, alpacas and a couple of spitting vicunas! Huge condors, and the star of the show was the owner's Peruvian Hairless dog! He's so ugly he's cute. It was also fun to see how the weaver's use natural dyes in coloring their yarn. There was a lady there weaving that had the fastest fingers I've ever seen. This is a fun, relaxing stop!!

Great Attraction on your way to Pisaq. My family and I stopped here with our tour guide on our way to the Pisaq market. This was one of the highlights of our trip. You got to see many Peruvian animals that have been rescued. We saw llamas, alpacas, pumas, condors, macaws, etc. It was great!!! The people that work there are knowledgeable and passionate about the animals. The tour is free, but please make sure to leave a contribution/ tip since it is how this sanctuary survives. They have a great gift shop with things for every price range.

A great stop on the way to Pisac. A neat little place where they care for abandoned former pets. An interesting hodgepodge of species. The highlight is the condor flight.There is not charge, but you should expect to buy some souvenirs at the end of your visit. The souvenir prices were reasonable.

A fun and educational side trip. We stopped by this sanctuary as part of a day tour of the Sacred Valley, and we definitely enjoyed getting close to some of the unique animals of Peru including 2 of the animals sacred to the Inca (the Puma and the Condor). It is a small place but everyone is enthusiastic; I particularly enjoyed the demonstration of how natural dyes are made for the alpaca wool. A visit to the gift shop is a great way to support this organization.

Rehab facility for the injured. Great job these people are doing, the sanctuary was free of charge to visit, a donation is gratefully accepted on exit... and a free gift given as a thank you.We saw the condors up close and personal, llamas, macaws, pumas, guinea pigs and heaps more. Be supportive and visit this amazing place. Do it for the animals.

Wonderful place to spend a few hours. This was included in one of our tours and we thoroughly enjoyed this visit, where they rehab injured animals. We were lucky to see the condors up close - they are huge, pumas, macaws, alpacas, llamas, all sorts of interesting animals. We gave a donation at the end of our visit and we received a free gift as a thank you. Very enjoyable.

Great place to see some rare animals. This animal sanctuary is a really neat place to see some rare rescued animals up close and personal. You can take lots of pictures and even interact with some of the animals. The tour guides speak English and explain all of the animals and where they were rescued from. We saw turtles, llamas, parrots, a puma, swans, condors... the condors even flew right over top of us. There is no entrance fee, but they do encourage donations. Our hotel called a taxi for us, and it was 80 soles round trip to take us there and back to our hotel in Cusco. My only complaint was that I would have liked more time in the santuary to interact with the animals, it felt a bit rushed even though we were the only customers/guests there.

See Rescued Animals for Release. Great work by volunteers and donations to rehabilitate rescued animals from local areas and the Amazon and prepare them for release back into their habitat. Terrific opportunity to see some rare species and get close to many.No entry fee, but after your tour, if you're not motivated to make a donation you obviously don't have a heart.

Cochahuasi Animal Sanctuary. I enjoyed the tour and seeing the animals (especially Condors, Pumas & Macaws). The sanctuary is small but they seem to be doing good work and it´s an interesting thing to do for a morning or afternoon in Cusco away from the main tourist haunts. Lots of people don´t seem to know about it so if you want to go just go to the main square (Plaza de Armas) and near the fountain there are representatives from the sanctuary and they have a bus to take you there (once you pay for the bus the entrance and guided tour are free/included). There are also some nice alpaca textiles that you can buy if you want some souvenirs which will also support the sanctuary.

short & perfect day trip. if you have 2 hrs to spare, take this trip! for 25 soles well spent, a shuttle from Plaza de Armas will take you to and from the animal sanctuary. Once there, you will get a 45 min guided tour of the intimate sanctuary. The stories about each of the animals there is wonderful, and the sensitivity they have towards each animal is noticeable and appreciated. The super-friendly deer and baby alpacas are a definite highlight, as well as the beautiful macaw parrots and close encounters with the condors and Peruvian hairless dog. Super cool. The education the staff provides is awesome. I actually loved learning about the process of processing and coloring the alpaca hair/fabric. Any donation and purchase goes to a good cause! So worth the short time investment!

The world needs more people like these people. I absolutely loved this place. I was impressed with the volunteer guide and his presentation about each animal. The surroundings in which the animsls are kept are clean, accommodating of their individual needs. The condor show is spectacular. The shop overcharged me for some items but I figured it was all going to a good cause so didn't mind.Not many tour operators want to take you here. It's not flash or showy - just down to earth, back to basics where people show respect for abused animals in a caring environment run on the smell of an oily rag. Do yourself a favour and visit. They will appreciate your donation and you'll be rewarded as well.

Great little animal rescue operation. On the way from Cuzco to Urubamba if you go Via Pizac (Longer but with great things to see.) A small group of very dedicated animal lovers have Condors, Pumas and other rescued animal you can see. You can even go in the Condor Pen and they fly over you.Great stop over and buy a t shirt or some Lama wool and you will be helping a great cause

Small but nice. First, I would like to say that this is a very small sanctuary. I expected a slightly larger area with more animals. However, other that that, my experience at the animal sanctuary was very good. My tour guide spoke good English. He also seemed to be very knowledgeable, friendly, and, most important of all, to genuinely care about the animals there at the sanctuary as well as elsewhere in Peru. There is a nice little gift shop toward the entrance/exit of the sanctuary and I got several very great photos with native birds. Overall, this was a very good experience. My advice to others: just do not expect a really long time at the sanctuary. It can be completed by 90% of people in 15-45 minutes just depending on how much time they chose to spend on each step of the tour. My favorite parts of the tour were listening to the small baby animals and standing right beside a very large, very sociable acting native bird.

Enthusiastic staff. Enjoyed my visit, caring staff but 3 pumas and 4 condors, not sure there is much conservation. Funded by donation. Good exhibition of wool dyes. They force 3 condors to fly for food. Having seen condors in the wild later in our holiday felt sorry for the 4 here

unique experience for a great cause. I had wanted to check out this place since reading about it on Tripadvisor...but wasn't sure how to reach it on my own (not many locals knew about this either!). It turns out that they send out shuttle buses to the Plaza de armas in Cusco twice daily (not sure what time they come in the morning, but the afternoon is at 3pm). Look for reps wearing green vests, round trip costed 25 soles.Upon arrival, I was greeted by one of the workers who explained in detail in English about each animal (where they came from, what Cochahuasi is doing for them..etc). Saw many of the endangered animals up close, including the flights of the 3 condors.They do ask for a voluntary donation but were not pushy at all in the end. they also have a shop selling beautiful locally made textiles and clothing/accessories, with the proceeds going back to the sancutary.Overall an unique experience in Cusco, highly recommended for anyone wishing to go off the typical "touristy" path in Cusco and learn more about these endangered animals.

Small, simple but perfect to see animals up close. This is a really small center where they rehabilitate animals from the andes and some from the amazon. I think they do a great job, the animals looked good and are taken good care of. It's simple but the volunteers speak English and can tell about the animals they have. You also have the possibility to stand right next to a condor, that was amazing.

lovely!. this is an incredible place to visit for those loving animals, I would say that when you come out after the visit, you feel yourself relieved thinking that people take care of the animals, struggling against the illegal hunting and commerce, ah! and you can take great pics.

Worth your time.. My brother and I hired a taxi for the day to see the Sacred Valley. We stopped here and it was worth the whole day's trip. I have seen a condor refuge outside of Otavalo, Ecuador, but they did not fly over my head. Enjoy the picture.
Please visit and contribute!. This very special sanctuary for endangered and injured animals relies on donations from the public. See condors in flight and learn about the local animals.

Small but wonderful sanctuary!. It wasn't the most amazing thing I did in Peru, but you get to see a condor fly, and the people are very friendly. They speak English too, so you can have a tour in English if you want.

Tremendous!. What a superb find! Truly delightful! On the road to Pizac is this little animal sanctuary where they have accepted injured or abused animals. The staff are quite charming and you will see more Peruvian animals in five minutes than you will during the rest of your holiday. This includes Pumas, wild Andean cats, unusual mammals and you will even see Condors flying. Quite fascinating and very interesting. Do visit them and support them: no entry fee, just a donation or buy something from their small shop if you wish. Probably one of the best local attractions for adults and children alike.

TRIP HIGHLIGHT, AS PROMISED. Last year another family told us that their kids loved this place above all else during their trip to Cuzco. It held true. This was probably my kids' favorite place to visit while we were in the Cuzco area. Seeing the condors was the highlight, and also a territorial Vicuna (who knew?) up close. :)
Had a great time. We loved our visit here. The pumas didn't come out of their "cave" but the condors were really amazing to see and very friendly!

Must see if you're close by.. First off I'm shocked by a few of the comments. One guy states he thinks the animals would be better served in the wild. These animals are in a sancuary because they can not function in the wild. You will see some of the animals are injured. You will have a condor fly right by your head and get as close to them as you like. The staff who I imagine are volunteers are very helpful and friendly. They even gave us an awesome whistle for donating. 5 stars for sure!

Best place to find exotic animals. I saw a lot of animals, like condor, puma, birds of different colors, etc. The staff was very friendly and gave us the tour of the place. This place took care of animals that were abused. They sell some scarves, sweaters, etc. and the earnings go to protecting these animals.
Animals saved here. A 20 min trip from Cusco. Get to see a Condor, Llamas, Vicunia and Alpacas. Free, but you can donate any amount, it goes to saving these animals.

Once in a lifetime experience having condors up close and personal. A magnificent opportunity to see rare Peruvian native species and help a wonderful cause. Ask to see it as most tours skip this gem.

Condors, Amazon parrots and Puma's. Our family loved every moment of this sanctuary, up close and friendly with massive condors, hand feeding rare parrots, whilst seeing puma's recovering from human interaction. The guides are great and kids will just love it as you enter the condor cage and see and feel them fly over your head. A wonderful morning

GREAT EXPERIENCE!. Great things come in small sizes! This place is great... lots of animals, all rescues, way better than forking your money over to a Zoo. Staff was very friendly, and the Condors flying over your head is something which words will not do justice.... definitely recommend this place to all my friends!

Way to see a condor up close. During our day trip in the Sacred valley, our taxi driver recommended stopping here and it was worth it. It's a great initiative to protect and rehabilate animals that were in captivity/poor conditions and are not fit to reenter the wild.The lady who showed us the different animals and told us about how they came into the shelter's care was very passionate and informative. She also shared information about the species and some of the challenges these species face in the wild.There is a nice gift shop or you can make a donation to the center if you want. An added bonus is that you can see condors from up close (less than 4 meters away).

Fantastic. We visted here today and really enjoyed ourselves. It's obvious how much they care for the animals and are passionate about showing the public around. I'm not a fan of zoos at all and was a little apprehensive before visiting as I hate seeing animals behind bars but the stories behind each animal and the rehabilitation that occurs here is very positive. There are lots of parrots and macaws which are free to come and go when they please! Remember to give a generous donation as this place depends on it!
Healing animals of South America. We stopped on our tour of the Sacred Valley. It was worth it to see so many animals up close. We also enjoyed the weaving and shopping at the store.

Rare Opportunity. Sharon and I dropped in here on our way to Pisaq Markets in the Sacred Valley about 20 minutes out of Cusco.We were warmly welcomed and escorted (probably a little bit quickly) through the complex by a English speaking attendant which helped immensely with our understanding of the animals in the Sanctuary.It is really very small and the visit only took about 30 minutes but gave us the rare opportunity to see Condors up close and see Pumas ... all be it in a very small enclosure.We couldn't quite decide whether this was in fact a real sanctuary where the animals were offered time to come back to some health to be repatriated or whether it was a zoo for the benefit of the tourist trade ... the rhetoric while we were there was all about animal welfare and rescue so I will give these guys the benefit of the doubt.A good opportunity to see some S American animals up close.We left a generous donation which was warmly received.Drop by and support them ... animal welfare in S America is hard work.

Something a little different. For 20 soles a person they will drive you out to visit this rescue center with condors, parrots, vicuña, even a tortoise. They are providing a home and rehab for injured or endangered animals and will ask for a small donation. They also have many lovely things in their gift shop, with profits going to the animal's care.

They need some help. Animals looked well cared for except the macaws, they need to be moved into a heated area. Trying to do good work but should work closer with governmental agency like Inrena to meet government standards. Not worth the taxi ride out to see this attraction. It's a rehabilitation center not a zoo, so don't expect to see many healthy animals.
Wonderful animal experience. We stopped by as part of an animal volunteer project. This sanctuary was a great stop on our tour. Really interesting - nice to see animals "living happily" together.

Great way to see Peruvian animals up close. I had been trying to get good pics of the Condors and Acunas earlier in the trip but couldn't, as they were in nature. But here in the sanctuary it was nice to see them up close and also being cared for by loving and attentive staff. It's a great thing to support and I definitely did! I wish I could've stayed longer!

Feeding Llamas and Condors Grazing your Head!. We stopped by this animal rescue on our way to the Sacred Valley of Pisac and absolutely loved it. We learned a great deal about the animals in the Andes region and were able to pet & feed different varieties of Llamas & Alpacas and even see condor feed while we were in their cage!The animals are lovely, as are the staff. It is worth stopping by if you're headed to Pisac from Cusco and PLEASE support their cause!

Loved this place - would recommend visiting it. This is one of our favourite places we have been on our trip so far. We pulled in as we travelled from Cusco to Pisac.Most of the animals are rescued and you don't pay to get it but give a donation or buy something from their shop.I love places like this where they are helping animals and the people who worked there were really friendly and willed the Condors to fly over you!A great little place that isn't advertised as much as it should be.

A nice thing to support. This is an excellent opportunity to see some of the south american wildlife. Thank goodness someone sis doing this. The birds are gorgeous and there is some wild cats that are a beautiful also.

Love the Condor fly by. This place is great, we take our guests here often and they allwayse love it. The people at Cochahuasi are providing abused and misstreated animals with a safe and caring enviroment and do their best to rehabilitat and release back to the wild any animals they can. The highlight of the visit is when they take you into the Condor enclosure and draw the birds down from the top with food, The Condors will typically fly right over your head, I have even had wingtips graze my hat on occation. I highly recoment this to anyone traveling to Pisac, the entrance fee is very reasonable (donation) and you would be helping support the animals.

Bigger and Better. This was my second visit to Cochahuasi and I was very impressed with the improvements since my last visit 2 years ago. More animals and better enclosures, especially for the pumas. They have added a fiber and weaving demo and the gift shop is now truly impressive. They seem to have more visitors now, which is great, although the guides were a little rushed and too quickly herded us to the shop when another group showed up. Still, their mission is important and I'm sure they'll find the right balance. And, of course, the condors are amazing!

Take the time to visit here!. I am a veterinarian and my husband found this place online prior to our trip. Needless to say, I had to visit, and I was not disappointed. The sanctuary is full of beautiful and well taken care of animals that each have an interesting and often sad story about how they ended up there. Some of the animals here included pumas, macaw parrots, guanacos, vicunas, Andean condors, storks, and white tail deer. One of the staff members greeted us as soon as we arrived and proceeded to show us around the sanctuary. She took us inside the Andean Condor enclosure, which was absolutely incredible. These birds are huge and will fly right over your head while you are in the enclosure. It is unlike anything you'll experience in the US. The Condors hopped around us and acted curious while our guide explained to us how endangered they are and that they hope to soon start a breeding program at the facility. It costs nothing to visit the sanctuary but they do accept donations, which we gladly gave. This place is a little bit of a drive outside of Cusco but we easily got there by taxi and it was well worth it.

Well worth a visit. The sanctuary are doing great things for the animals and it is worth taking time out to stop to visit whether you are heading to Pisac or Cusco. The kids loved it as did the grown-ups. A nice variety of animals to view. Payment is by donation and the guides tell you in full detail how long the animals had been there and how they were discovered.

Gem of the Area!. Our tour guide stopped with us here last minute. We loved the chance to view so many animals up close. (This is a rescue animal place if you weren't aware.) We saw condors, macaws, pumas, a stork, vicuña, llama, alpacas, turtles, and I'm sure I'm forgetting something! A young man walked us thru the whole area explaining every animal too. It's definitely worth your time to look this place up.

Face to face with condors. It's a wonderful little place to visit. Not really signposted and a bit out of the way so a taxi is probably the best way to get there unless you are on a tour that stops there. Entry is free, donations and/or buying from the gift shop is encouraged. Volunteer show you around and tell you the stories of how the animals got rescued, what they do at the sanctuary to help rehabilitate, their breeding programs and why some of them can no longer be released into the wild. There's a big collection of native animals - puma, Andean deer (which you can feed), macaws from 3 countries, alpaca, llama, vicuna, tortoise, a baby toucan and of course, the 3 majestic condors. There's also a pet hairless Peruvian dog. We learnt a lot of interesting facts about the types of animals as well as the individuals. As others have mentioned, you get to go into the condor cage and see them fly over your head, as well as get up close and person to have a good look at them. Absolutely amazing experience!

Worth the short trip to be next to Condors. I would have missed this as a tour because the tour was being sold on the Street. I was amazed to find out and in fact did stand right next to two condors with their wings spread open. The place is safe and a very nice drive over the mountains overlooking Cusco. The dive took about a half hour at 35 mph. There are also Pumas, llamas, al pacas, etc. Even though caged, this is up close and the animals seem well cared for. The cost was only 20 soles for everything. This appears to be non-profit and they do accept donations but they do not ask for them or push anything on you. I highly recommend if you want to see condors up close and personal.

a do not miss site. I read about this on WikiTravel which I will always consult from now on as well as Lonely Planet which did not include. This fine family does not charge you to observe at close range pumas, tortoises, vicunas, jungle cats and the mighty Andean condors. Clean surroundings and where else would you EVER see a flying condor at 20 feet? Donations accepted. Be charitable when buying from the excellent store there and-or leaving a healthy donation to this altruistic family.

Hidden Treasures. Our private guide recommended this locale and it was amazing, educational and would highly recommend a stop. The Cochahuasi guide provided a very compelling explanation of the history of the animals and how they came to live at this sanctuary. You get a very close up, hands on type of tour. There is no charge to visit, but they ask for donations or you can shop at their store. The woven goods that they sell are all locally made and are the finest that I saw in Peru. The textiles are worthy of any museum store. The clerks will also explain the story woven into each piece.... ranging from wall hangings, to scarves, ponchos, bedspreads, all exquisite and made from the various wools, naturally dyed. To me, this was one of the well hidden highlights of Peru. Highly recommend for the mission, the animals, the textiles and for the local families that are supported by the sales in the store. This whole area is so beautiful and the Santuario is no exception.

Get up close with native animals. This was a lot of fun and a great short stop on our way back from Pisac to Cusco. We stopped for about 45 minutes. Our guide spoke very good English ANC showed and explained how they got many animals, including vicunas, pumas, and condors.Seeing the hugs condors fly by was impressive, and they took our picture with it, too.They had a nice shop with quality items for sale, and a donation box where we could choose to give to support their animal rescue efforts. Overall a great stop!

Get buzed by a Condor. This is an interesting place to visit that not only affords you the opportunity to see a variety of Peruvian animals, but is also doing some good in the process. Aside from rescuing a variety of animals, the center is also hoping to start a Condor breeding program to help increase the number of wild condors. The center is does not charge any admission and only requests donations, it is also the only place I know in the Cusco area where you can be buzzed by a condor.

Got blessed by a Condor!. During my all day Sacred Valley tour, the Ccochahuasi sanctuary was my first stop.By Northern American standards, it's small and some animals are in rather tight caging. However the people running the sanctuary and making the effort to save animals native to their country. My guide gave me insight in the various animals and why there are there. Some were there due to illegal smuggling, others because of injuries, some because the lost of habitat,etc.I will admit that learning the difference between Ilamas, Alpacas, Guanacos, and Vicuna was helpful.The Puma stayed in his area and didn't see him.There are several colorful parrots on site. There are also three Condors. The guide went to get food for them and told me when they start flying down to duck. The first time I thought that I ducked low enough. But I got brushed on my left side (almost knocked down) when he came flying. The second time I knew to duck lower!! The guide told me to me touched by a Condor will bring good luck, we will see!!The next area has a local woman demonstrating weaving techniques and the use of items for natural dyes. I got to get a great viewing and demo being the only person there.The guide requested a donation for the sanctuary. She wasn't pushy about it and grateful for the assistance.There is a small shop with Alpaca items on sale. I did purchased items that were reasonable in cost.While it don't look like much, stop by and pay a visit to learn about animals native to Peru

By chance a gem. We visited CCOCHAHUASI on our way from Pisac to Cusco. First the llama-Alpaca Ranch where we hand fed and mingled with them. Now we know the difference between llama, Alpaca, Vincuna and guanacos.Then across the road to the sanctuary. Puma, Condors, parrots, and many more. And a guide tells you about each and the rescues and some sad stories, and some happy ones. And to be in the aviary with the condors ...............It´s all free and all they ask is a donation and not in any demanding way.Yes easy to criticise them on cage size (see below - but they are far bigger, cleaner and better than many zoos) but these people care and have got off their backsides and are doing something. Lovely animals, lovely people, educational, and great feeling to be able to help in a tiny way. Highly recommended and it is on most peoples routes to and from the valley.

Worth A Stopover. A small place, but worth it. About 30 minutes outside of Cusco, on the way to Pisac. The highlight is the 3 Peruvian Condors which are huge! They let you get right next to them, and they will fly off which is kind of nerve racking considering how large they are. They even make a swooshing sound when they fly because of their size. They had 3 pumas though only 1 was visible, and other animals though not much. They ask for donations at the end and have a gift shop which helps them. Spent about 45 min there as a guide walked us through.

Interesting, great chance to see condors.. We found a volunteer handing out flyers in plaza de armas. We had a taxi take us there and back for 20 soles (£5) for 40 mins journey each way. The place itself is very run down , no sign on outside u would drive past not knowing it was there. We had a volunteer show us round , which felt quite rushed. The enclosures were in bad conditions and in need of repair. We were told the stories of how the animals came to sanctuary and it was encouraging to hear that some animals are released into wild. The enclosure with the condors was amazing experience, there were 3 in there and u got to see them fly. At the end of visit u can choose free pen or whistle which was sweet. There is shop and small snack hut.we gave 50 soles donation. Visit Here if u want seething different to do and if u want to support a worthy charity!

A Must See in the Sacred Valley. This is sort of an animal rescue/zoo/educational venue that is a must see. We also didn't have this on our itinerary and it was empty, so I suspect that it doesn't get visited by most tour programs, but our local guide thought that our kids would like it and it was one of the main highlights for us in the Sacred Valley, Cusco Peru. It isn't very commercialized like many "petting zoos" in the sacred valley that let you feed alpaca and llama, but it has a much better mission and has a broader selection of endangered animals. Please try to support them with a donation or purchase when you visit. The Condors and Puma are amazing.

Great Place to see Condors. This is a great place, run by animal lovers, the animals come from neglect, or are seized animals, some are rehabilitated to the wild some will stay forever due to the abuse they suffered, it is well worth your time to see.

Condors, pumas y mucho mas!. This place was one of the highlights of my visit to Peru, but it was not on our group itinerary. We heard about it from some locals. It is run by two brothers, I think, with science backgrounds, who decided someone had to do something to educate people about the poaching of condors and declining populations and mistreatment of other animals native to the Andes. They rescue, rehabilitate and release, if possible, many species of animals. But the main attraction is the condors. They actually had a breeding pair, and were releasing young birds to the wild each year.I think it's important to see past the touristy veneer and get at least a glimpse of the real Peru, the real people and the real problems. The Santuario Animal Cochahuasi is a good place to start. But you will probably have to make your own arrangements to get there. Though it is right on a highly traveled road between Cusco and Pisaq, at the time I was there (July 2011) the owners said they didn't get too many tourists because they refused to pay the tour guides to stop there. They wanted every dollar possible to go directly to the animals. This is a don't-miss attraction in the Sacred Valley. They are dedicated to the important work they are doing, and your donation dollars (there is no admission fee) will help immensely. They have a great little gift shop, as well, and you can be assured your purchases are furthering the work.

Pumas and Condors. Something you do not expect to see, but if you have time stop there and see how in simple way, the family who works there have a great intention in the protection of some species in danger. A photo with the condors was awesome.

Nice. We had a lot of fun here- the animals were well treated and the guide was very nice. We got to see pumas, condors, llamas, alpacas, dogs and parrots. The kids got to hold the parrots on their arms and after they were also allowed to carefully hold puppies. We had a great time!! Nice souvenir shop. Donations are highly appreciated there. Recommended!!

One of my peru highlights. One of the best things i did my whole trip, about a 30min-45min drive out of cusco, nice scenic drive. no entrance fee, runs on donations and a store they have. was greeted by a young tour guide, told us all about every animal in there, how they got there, if they can be released again or not, what they eat, and what eats them. pumas, peru deer, alpacas, lamas, parrots, jungle cat kittens, birds of prey, Condors, and a few others. condors have a nice large avairy that you can walk in and get pretty close to the big birds and get nice pictures. and they show you where they get the colours for the alpaca wool, like certain rocks and plants for different colours. they have a large shop to buy many fine baby alpaca times and other animal items and sculptures. with a donation you get a parting gift of a wooden condor whistle, a really nice unexpected treat. A great small sanctuary worth seeing and a worthy cause to donate to.there is also a alpaca/lama petting ranch just down the road, only 4 or 5 pens, but a few different kinds and you can hand feed them, ask for grass if there is none out. also on donations, and has a shop that serves alcohol! haha.

A must-see for any animal-lover who visits Cuzco or the Sacred Valley. Whever I travel, I try to support local animal charities, shelters, or humane organizations who care for animals. When in Peru, I looked for such a group prior to traveling and found this sole review for the Ccochahuasi Animal Sanctuary. I visited the sanctuary in May 2012 and was very impressed with the facility, the experienced guides and the up-close-and-personal experiences with unqie animals offered at this facility. It is approximately 45 minutes from Cuzco and admission is free - the center survives off visitor donations and certainly I was happy to give them one for the important work they do for animals in the region - rescuing them when injured or when traded illegally in the black market. We say many animals - including pumas and bobcats - but the flight of the magnificent condors was perhaps the highlight of the visit - these exquisite birds (wing span of up to 11 feet) flying so close that the force of their wings moves your hair. It was nothing short of spectacular. The guides are friendly and informed and seemed prepared to speak with travellers from many nationalities speaking many languages. I encourage any animal-lovers to visit the Sanctuary - help the animals by donating to this worthy cause - and bring back some souvenirs for your loved ones that go a long way to supporting the wildlife in Peru.

A great program. Our guide asked if we wanted to visit a "zoo" on the way to Pisac. I was not so interested but she said it had condors and you could see the animals close up. So, we decided to stop not expecting much. We were quite glad we did. We were able to go inside the condor aviary and actually touch them. We saw several other animals as well that have been rescued from injury or bad situations. Some are in cages and others in an open area. There are llamas, hairless dog, tortoise, parrots and birds, coati, etc. They educate on why we should not buy souvenirs that use condor feathers and other important ways to help the animals and birds in Peru. They exist on donations from visitors to this place. It is definitely worth the 45 minutes it would take to visit here.
